text: the immediate problems centring round the concepts of matter, life, and

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: its own logic and a new and more promising spirit of reflection on its

text: own "categories" is abroad. Things are turning out to be very far from

text: what they seemed. The physicists have come to a point where, it may be

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: methods than those to which they have been accustomed are required. At
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: any rate, they and the large public which hangs upon their words show a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: (sometimes an uncritical anxiety) to hear what he has to say.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: No one needs to be reminded of the ferment which is moving in the world
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of social affairs, of the obscure but powerful tendencies which are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: forcing society out of its grooves and leaving it, aspiring but dubious,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: in new and uncharted regions. This may affect different minds in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: different ways. Some regret it, others rejoice in it; but all are aware
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of it. Time-honoured political and economic formulae are become "old
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: clothes" for an awakened and ardent generation, and before the new
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: garments are quite ready; the blessed word "reconstruction" is often
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: mentioned. Men are not satisfied that society has really developed so

text: successfully as it might have done; many believe that it finds itself in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a cul-de-sac. But what is to be done? The experienced can see that many
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: of the offered reforms are but the repetition of old mistakes which will
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: involve us in the unhappy cycle of disillusion and failure. It is not to

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: and the true outcome of human effort, to be an inspiration and a guide
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: to them in their pathetic struggle out of the morass in which they, too
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: CHAPTER II
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: THE REALITY OF CHANGE
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Fundamental in Bergson's philosophy. We are surrounded by changes--we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ourselves change--Belief in change--Simplicity of change--Immobility
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is composite and relative--All movement is indivisible. The fallacy of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "states"--Intellect loves the static--Life is dynamic--Change, the very
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: stuff of life, constitutes reality.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Throughout the history of thought we find that the prevailing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophies have always reflected some of the characteristics of their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: time. For instance, in those periods when, as historians tell us, the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: tendency towards unity, conformity, system, order, and authority was
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: strong, we find philosophy reflecting these conditions by emphasizing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the unity of the universe; while in those periods in which established
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: order, system, and authority were disturbed, the philosophy of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: time emphasizes the idea of multiplicity as opposed to the unity of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the universe, laying stress on freedom, creative action, spontaneity of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: effort, and the reality of change. There can be little doubt that this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is the chief reason why Bergson's philosophy has found such an amount of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: acceptance in a comparatively short period. The response to his thought
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: may be explained very largely by this, that already his fundamental
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ideas existed, although implicit, unexpressed, in the minds of a great
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: multitude of thoughtful people, to whom the static conceptions of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: universe were inadequate and false.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We must not, on the other hand, overlook the fact that Bergson's
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: statements have in their turn given an emphasis to all aspects of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thought which take account of the reality of change and which realize
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: its importance in all spheres. A writer on world politics very aptly
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reminds us that "life is change, and a League of Peace that aimed at
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: preserving peace by forbidding change would be a tyranny as oppressive
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as any Napoleonic dictatorship. These problems called for periodic
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: change. The peril of our future is that, while the need for change
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is instinctively grasped by some peoples as the fundamental fact of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: world-politics, to perceive it costs others a difficult effort of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thought." [Footnote: H. N. Brailsford on Peace and Change, Chap. 3 of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: his Book A League of Nations.] However difficult it may be for some
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: individuals and for some nations to grasp it, the great fact is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there--the reality of change is undeniable.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson himself would give to his philosophy the title, The Philosophy
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Change, and this for a very good reason, for the principle of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Change and an insistence on its reality lies at the root of his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thought.[Footnote: He suggested this as a sub-title to Dr. H. Wildon
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Carr for his little work Henri Bergson (People's Books). Dr. Wildon
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Carr's later and larger work bears this as its full title.] "We know
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that everything changes," we find him saying in his London lectures,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "but it is mere words. From the earliest times recorded in the history
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of philosophy, philosophers have never stopped saying that everything
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: changes; but, when the moment came for the practical application of this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: proposition, they acted as if they believed that at the bottom of things
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there is immobility and invariability. The greatest difficulties of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophy are due to not taking account of the fact that Change and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Movement are universal. It is not enough to say that everything changes
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and moves--we must believe it." [Footnote: Second of the four lectures on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: La Nature de l'Ame delivered at London University, Oct. 21, 1911. From
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: report in The Times for Oct. 23, 1911, p. 4.] In order to think Change
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and to see it, a whole mass of prejudices must be swept aside--some
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: artificial, the products of speculative philosophy, and others the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: natural product of common-sense. We tend to regard immobility as a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: more simple affair than movement. But what we call immobility is really
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: composite and is merely relative, being a relation between movements.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: If, for example, there are two trains running in the same direction on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: parallel lines at exactly the same speed, opposite one another, then the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: passengers in each train, when observing the other train, will regard
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the trains as motionless. So, generally, immobility is only apparent,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Change is real. We tend to be misled by language; we speak, for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: instance, of 'the state of things'; but what we call a state is the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: appearance which a change assumes in the eyes of a being who, himself,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: changes according to an identical or analogous rhythm. "Take, for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: example," says Bergson, "a summer day. We are stretched on the grass, we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: look around us--everything is at rest--there is absolute immobility--no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: change. But the grass is growing, the leaves of the trees are developing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or decaying--we ourselves are growing older all the time. That which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: seems rest, simplicity itself, is but a composite of our ageing with the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: changes which takes place in the grass, in the leaves, in all that is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: around us. Change, then, is simple, while 'the state of things' as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we call it, is composite. Every stable state is the result of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: co-existence between that change and the change of the person who
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: perceives it." [Footnote: La Nature de l'Ame, lecture 2.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: It is an axiom in the philosophy of Bergson that all change or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement is indivisible. He asserts this expressly in Matter and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Memory,[Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 246 ff. (Fr. p. 207 ff).] and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: again in the second lecture on The Perception of Change he deals with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the indivisibility of movement somewhat fully, submitting it to a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: careful analysis, from which the following quotation is an extract--"My
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: hand is at the point A. I move it to the point B, traversing the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: interval AB. I say that this movement from A to B is a simple
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thing--each of us has the sensation of this, direct and immediate.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Doubtless, while we carry our hand over from A to B, we say to ourselves
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that we could stop it at an intermediate point, but then that would no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: longer be the same movement. There would then be two movements, with an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: interval of rest. Neither from within, by the muscular sense, nor from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: without, by sight, should we have the same perception. If we leave our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement from A to B such as it is, we feel it undivided, and we must
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: declare it indivisible. It is true that when I look at my hand, going
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from A to B, traversing the interval AB, I say to myself 'the interval
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: AB can be divided into as many parts as I wish, therefore the movement
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from A to B can be divided into as many parts as I like, since this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement covers this interval,' or, again, 'At each moment of its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: passing, the moving object passes over a certain point, therefore we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: can distinguish in the movement as many stopping-places as we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: wish--therefore the movement is infinitely divisible.' But let us
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reflect on this for a minute. How can the movement possibly coincide
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with the space which it traverses? How can the moving coincide with the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: motionless? How can the object which moves be said to 'be' at any point
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in its path? It passes over, or, in other words, it could 'be' there. It
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: would 'be' there if it stopped there, but, if it stopped there, it is no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: longer the same movement with which we are dealing. It is always at one
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: bound that a trajectory is traversed when, on its course, there is no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: stoppage. The bound may last a few seconds, or it may last for weeks,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: months, or years, but it is unique and cannot be decomposed. Only, when
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: once the passage has been made, as the path is in space, and space is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: infinitely divisible, we picture to ourselves the movement itself as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: infinitely divisible. We like to imagine it thus, because, in a movement
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is not the change of position which interests us, it is the positions
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: themselves which the moving object has left, which it will take up,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which it might assume if it were to stop in its course. We have need
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of immobility, and the more we succeed in presenting to ourselves the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement as coinciding with the space which it traverses, the better we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: think we understand it. Really, there is no true immobility, if we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: imply by that, an absence of movement." [Footnote: Translated from La
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Perception du Changement, pp. 19-20.] This immobility of which we have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: need for the purposes of action and of practical life, we erect into an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: absolute reality. It is of course convenient to our sense of sight to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: lay hold of objects in this way; as pioneer of the sense of touch,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it prepares our action on the external world. But, although for all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: practical purposes we require the notion of immobility as part of our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mental equipment, it does not at all help us to grasp reality. Then we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: habitually regard movement as something superadded to the motionless.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: This is quite legitimate in the world of affairs; but when we bring this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: habit into the world of speculation, we misconceive reality, we create
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: lightheartedly insoluble problems, and close our eyes to what is most
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: alive in the real world. For us movement is one position, then another
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: position, and so on indefinitely. It is true that we say there must
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be something else, viz., the actual passing across the interval which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: separates those positions. But such a conception of Change is quite
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: false. All true change or movement is indivisible. We, by constructing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fictitious states and trying to compose movement out of them, endeavour
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to make a process coincide with a thing--a movement with an immobility.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: This is the way to arrive at dilemmas, antinomies, and blind-alleys of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thought. The puzzles of Zeno about "Achilles and the Tortoise" and "The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Moving Arrow" are classical examples of the error involved in treating
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement as divisible.[Footnote: Bergson in Matter and Memory examines
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Zeno's four puzzles: "The Dichotomy," "Achilles and the Tortoise," "The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Arrow" and "The Stadium."] If movement is not everything, it is nothing,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and if we postulate, to begin with, that the motionless is real, then
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we shall be incapable of grasping reality. The philosophies of Plato, of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Aristotle, and of Plotinus were developed from the thesis that there
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is more in the immutable than in the moving, and that it is by way of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: diminution that we pass from the stable to the unstable.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The main reason why it is such a difficult matter for us to grasp
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the reality of continuous change is owing to the limitations of our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intellectual nature. "We are made in order to act, as much as and more
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: than in order to think--or, rather, when we follow the bent of our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: nature, it is in order to act that we think." [Footnote: Creative
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Evolution, p. 313 (Fr. p. 321).] Intellect is always trying to carve out
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for itself stable forms because it is primarily fitted for action, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "is characterized by a natural inability to comprehend life" and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: grasp Change.[Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 174 (Fr. p. 179).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Our intellect loves the solid and the static, but life itself is not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: static--it is dynamic. We might say that the intellect takes views
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: across the ever-moving scene, snapshots of reality. It acts like the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: camera of the cinematograph operator, which is capable only of producing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: photographs, successive and static, in a series upon a ribbon. To grasp
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reality, we have to do what the cinematograph does with the film--that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is, introduce or rather, re-introduce movement.[Footnote: Creative
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Evolution, pp. 320-324 (Fr. pp. 328-332).] The stiff photograph is an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: abstraction bereft of movement, so, too, our intellectual views of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: world and of our own nature are static instead of being dynamic. Human
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life is not made up of childhood, adolescence, manhood, and old age as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "states," although we tend to speak of it in this way. Life is not a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thing, nor the state of a thing--it is a continuous movement or change.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The soul itself is a movement, not an entity. In the physical world,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: light, when examined, proves itself to be a movement. Even physical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: science, bound, as it would seem, to assert the fixity and rigidity of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: matter, is now of the opinion that matter is not the solid thing we are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: apt to think it. The experiments of Kelvin and Lodge and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: discovery of radium, have brought forward a new theory of matter; the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: old-fashioned base, the atom, is now regarded as being essentially
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement; matter is as wonderful and mysterious in its character
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as spirit. Further we must note that the researches of Einstein,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: culminating in the formulation of his general Theory of Relativity and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: his special Theory of Gravitation, which are arousing such interest at
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the present time, threaten very seriously the older static views of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the universe and seem to frustrate any efforts to find and denote any
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: stability therein.[Footnote: Consult on this Dr. Einstein's own work of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which the translation by R. W. Lawson is just published: Relativity: The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Special and the General Theory. Methuen, 1920.] In the light of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: these discoveries, Bergson's views on the reality of Change seem less
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: paradoxical than they might formerly have appeared. The reality of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Change is, for Bergson, absolute, and on this, as a fundamental point,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: he constructs his thought. In conjunction with his study of Memory, it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: leads up to his discussions of Real Time (la duree), of Freedom, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Creative Evolution. We must then, at the outset of any study of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson's philosophy, obtain a grasp of this universal 'becoming'--a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: vision of the reality of Change. Then we shall realize that Change is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: substantial, that it constitutes the very stuff of life. "There are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: changes, but there are not things that change; change does not need a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: support. There are movements, but there are not, necessarily, constant
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: objects which are moved; movement does not imply something that is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movable." [Footnote: Translated from La Perception du Changement, Lecture
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: To emphasize and to illustrate this point, so fundamental in his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thought, Bergson turns to music. "Let us listen," he says, "to a melody,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: letting ourselves be swayed by it; do we not have the clear perception
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of a movement which is not attached to any mobility--of a change devoid
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of anything which changes? The change is self-sufficient, it is the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thing itself. It avails nothing to say that it takes time, for it is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: indivisible; if the melody were to stop sooner, it would not be any
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: longer the same volume of sound, but another, equally indivisible.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Doubtless we have a tendency to divide it and to represent it to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ourselves as a linking together of distinct notes instead of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: uninterrupted continuity of the melody. But why? Simply because our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: auditive perception has assumed the habit of saturating itself with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: visual images. We hear the melody across the vision which the conductor
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the orchestra can have of it in looking at his score. We represent
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to ourselves notes linked on to notes on an imaginary sheet of paper.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We think of a keyboard on which one plays, of the bow of a violin which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: comes and goes, of the musicians, each one of whom plays his part in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conjunction with the others. Let us abstract these spatial images; there
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: remains pure change, self-sufficing, in no way attached to a 'thing'
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which changes." [Footnote: Translated from La Perception du Changement,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We must conceive reality as a continual flux, then immobility will
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: seem a superficial abstraction hypostatized into states, concepts, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: substances, and the old difficulties raised by the ancients, in regard
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to the problem of Change, will vanish, along with the problems attached
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to the notion of "substance" in modern thought, because there is nothing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: substantial but Change. Apart from Change there is no reality. We shall
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: see that all is movement, that we ourselves are movement--part of an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: elan, a poussee formidable, which carries with it all things and all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: creatures, and that in this eternity--not of immutability but of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life and Change--"we live and move and have our being." [Footnote: La
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Perception du Changement, concluding paragraph, p. 37.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: CHAPTER III
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: PERCEPTION
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Images as data--Nerves, afferent and efferent, cannot beget images, nor
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: can the brain give rise to representations--All our perception relative
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to action. Denial of this involves the fallacies of Idealism or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Realism--Perception and knowledge--Physiological data--Zone of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: indetermination--"Pure" perception--Memory and Perception.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: From the study of Change we are led on to a consideration of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: problems connected with our perception of the external world, which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: has its roots in change. These problems have given rise to some very
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: opposing views--the classic warfare between Realism and Idealism.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson is of neither school, but holds that they each rest on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: misconceptions, a wrong emphasis on certain facts. He invites us to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: follow him closely while he investigates the problems of Perception in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: his own way.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "We will assume for the moment that we know nothing of theories of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: matter and theories of spirit, nothing of the discussions as to the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reality or ideality of the external world. Here I am in the presence
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of images, in the vaguest sense of the word, images perceived when my
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: senses are opened to them, unperceived when they are closed. ... Now of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: these images there is ONE which is distinct from all the others, in that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: I do not know it only from without by perceptions, but from within by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: affections; it is my body." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 1 (Fr.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 1).] Further examination shows me that these affections "always
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: interpose themselves between the excitations from without and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement which I am about to execute." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 1
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Fr. p. 1).] Indeed all seems to take place as if, in this aggregate of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: images which I call the universe, nothing really new could happen except
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: through the medium of certain particular images, the type of which is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: furnished me by my body." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 3 (Fr. p. 2).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Reference to physiology shows in the structure of human bodies afferent
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: nerves which transmit a disturbance to nerve centres, and also efferent
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: nerves which conduct from other centres movement to the periphery, thus
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: setting in motion the body in whole or in part. When we make enquiries
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from the physiologist or the psychologist with regard to the origin of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: these images and representations, we are sometimes told that, as the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: centrifugal movements of the nervous system can evoke movement of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: body, so the centripetal movements--at least some of them--give rise to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the representation, mental picture, or perception of the external world.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Yet we must remember that the brain, the nerves, and the disturbance of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the nerves are, after all, only images among others. So it is absurd to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: state that one image, say the brain, begets the others, for "the brain
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is part of the material world, but the material world is not part of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: brain." Eliminate the image which bears the name 'material world,' and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: you destroy, at the same time, the brain and the cerebral disturbances
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which are parts of it. Suppose, on the contrary, that these two images,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the brain and the cerebral disturbance, vanish; ex hypothesi you efface
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: only these, that is to say, very little--an insignificant detail from an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: immense picture--the picture in its totality, that is to say, the whole
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: universe remains. To make of the brain the condition on which the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whole image depends is a contradiction in terms, since the brain is,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by hypothesis, a part of this image." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 4 (Fr. pp. 3-4).] The data of perception are external images, then my
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: body, and changes brought about by my body in the surrounding images.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The external images transmit movement to my body, it gives back movement
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to them. My body or part of my body, i.e., my brain, could not beget a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whole or part of my representation of the external world. "You may
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: say that my body is matter or that it is an image--the word is of no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: importance. If it is matter, it is a part of the material world, and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: material world consequently exists around it and without it. If it is an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: image--that image can give but what has been put into it, and since
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is, by hypothesis, the image of my body only, it would be absurd to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: expect to get from it that of the whole universe. My body, an object
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: destined to move other objects, is then a centre of action; it cannot
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: give birth to a representation." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 5 (Fr.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 4).] The body, however, is privileged, since it appears to choose
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: within certain limits certain reactions from possible ones. It exercises
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a real influence on other images, deciding which step to take among
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: several which may be possible. It judges which course is advantageous
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or dangerous to itself, by the nature of the images which reach it. The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: objects which surround my body reflect its possible action upon
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: them. All our perception has reference, primarily, to action, not to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: speculation.[Footnote: Cf. Creative Evolution, p. 313 (Fr. p. 321).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The brain centres are concerned with motor reaction rather than with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conscious perception, "the brain is an instrument of action and not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of representation." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 83 (Fr. p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 69).] Therefore, in the study of the problems of perception, the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: starting-point should be action and not sensation. All the confusions,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inconsistencies and absurdities of statement, made in regard to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our knowledge of the external world, have here their origin. Many
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophers and psychologists "show us a brain, analogous in its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: essence to the rest of the material universe, consequently an image, if
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the universe is an image. Then, since they want the internal movements
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of this brain to create or determine the representation of the whole
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: material world--an image infinitely greater than that of the cerebral
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: vibrations--they maintain that these molecular movements, and movement
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in general, are not images like others, but something which is either
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: more or less than an image--in any case is of another nature than an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: image--and from which representation will issue as by a miracle. Thus
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: matter is made into something radically different from representation,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: something of which, consequently, we have no image; over against it they
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: place a consciousness empty of images, of which we are unable to form
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: any idea. Lastly, to fill consciousness, they invent an incomprehensible
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: action of this formless matter upon this matterless thought." [Footnote:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Matter and Memory, p. 9 (Fr. pp. 7-8).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The problem at issue between Realists and Idealists turns on the fact
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that there are two systems of images in existence. "Here is a system of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: images which I term 'my perception of the universe,' and which may be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: entirely altered by a very slight change in the privileged image--my
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: body. This image occupies the centre. By it all the others are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conditioned; at each of its movements everything changes as though by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a turn of a kaleidoscope. Here, on the other hand, are the same images,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: but referred each one to itself, influencing each other no doubt, but in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: such a manner that the effect is always in proportion to the cause; this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is what I term the 'universe.'" [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 12 (Fr.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 10).] The question is, "How is it that the same images can belong
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: at the same time to two different systems--the one in which each image
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: varies for itself and in the well-defined measure that it is patient of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the real action of surrounding images--the other in which all change for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a single image and in the varying measure that they reflect the eventual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: action of this privileged image?" [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 13
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Fr. p. 11).] We may style one the system of science, the other the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: system of consciousness. Now, Realism and Idealism are both incapable
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of explaining why there are two such systems at all. Subjective
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Idealism derives the system of science from that of consciousness, while
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: materialistic Realism derives the system of consciousness from that of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: science. They have, however, this common meeting-place, that they both
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: regard Perception as speculative in character--for each of them "to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: perceive" is to "know." Now this is just the postulate which Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: disputes. The office of perception, according to him, is to give us,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: not knowledge, but the conditions necessary for action.[Footnote: Notre
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: croyance a la loi de causalite (Revue de metaphysique et de morale,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 1900), p. 658.] A little examination shows us that distance stands for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the degree in which other bodies are protected, as it were, against the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: action of my body against them, and equally too for the degree in which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: my body is protected from them.[Footnote: Le Souvenir du present et
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: la fausse reconnaissance in L'Energie spirituelle, pp. 117-161
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Mind-Energy), or Revue philosophique, 1908, pp. 561-593.] Perception
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is utilitarian in character and has reference to bodily action, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we detach from all the images coming to us those which interest us
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: practically.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson then examines the physiological aspects of the perceptual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: process. Beginning with reflex actions and the development of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: nervous system, he goes on to discuss the functions of the spinal cord
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and the brain. He finds in regard to these last two that "there is only
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a difference of degree--there can be no difference in kind--between what
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is called the perceptive faculty of the brain and the reflex functions
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the spinal cord. The cord transforms into movements the stimulation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: received, the brain prolongs into reactions which are merely nascent,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: but in the one case as in the other, the function of the nerve substance
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is to conduct, to co-ordinate, or to inhibit movements.[Footnote: Matter
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and Memory, pp. 10-11 (Fr. p. 9).] As we rise in the organic series
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we find a division of physiological labour. Nerve cells appear, are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: diversified and tend to group themselves into a system; at the same time
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the animal reacts by more varied movements to external stimulation.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: But even when the stimulation received is not at once prolonged
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: into movement, it appears merely to await its occasion; and the same
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: impression which makes the organism aware of changes in the environment,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: determines it or prepares it to adapt itself to them. No doubt there is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in the higher vertebrates a radical distinction between pure automatism,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of which the seat is mainly in the spinal cord, and voluntary activity
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which requires the intervention of the brain. It might be imagined
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that the impression received, instead of expanding into more movements
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: spiritualizes itself into consciousness. But as soon as we compare the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: structure of the spinal cord with that of the brain, we are bound to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: infer that there is merely a difference of complication, and not a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: difference in kind, between the functions of the brain and the reflex
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: activity of the medullary system." [Footnote: Matter and Memory,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: pp. 17-18 (Fr. p. 15).] The brain is no more than a kind of central
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: telephone exchange, its office is to allow communication or to delay
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it. It adds nothing to what it receives, it is simply a centre where
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: perceptions get into touch with motor mechanisms. Sometimes the function
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the brain is to conduct the movement received to a chosen organ of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reaction, while at other times it opens to the movement the totality
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the motor tracks. The brain appears as an instrument of analysis in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: regard to movements received by it, but an instrument of selection in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: regard to the movements executed. In either case, its office is limited
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to the transmission and division of movements. In the lower organisms,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: stimulation takes the form of immediate contact. For example, a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: jelly-fish feels a danger when anything touches it, and reacts
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: immediately. The more immediate the reaction has to be, the more it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: resembles simple contact. Higher up the scale, sight and hearing enable
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the individual to enter into relation with a greater number of objects
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and with objects at a distance. This gives rise to an amount of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: uncertainty, "a zone of indetermination," where hesitation and choice
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: come into play. Hence, says Bergson: "Perception is master of space in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the exact measure in which action is master of time." [Footnote: Matter
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and Memory, p. 23 (Fr. p. 19).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In the paper read before the First International Congress of Philosophy
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: at Paris in 1900, on Our Belief in the Law of Causality,[Footnote: Notre
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: croyance a la loi de causalite (Revue de metaphysique et de morale,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Sept., 1900, pp. 655-660).] Bergson showed that it has its root in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: co-ordination of our tactile impressions with our visual impressions.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: This co-ordination becomes a continuity which generates motor habits or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: tendencies to action.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: There now comes up for consideration the question as to why this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: relation of the organism, to more or less distinct objects, takes
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the particular form of conscious perception, and further, why does
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: everything happen as if this consciousness were born of the internal
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movements of the cerebral substance? To answer this question, we must
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: turn to perceptual processes, as these occur in our everyday life. We
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: find at once that "there is no perception which is not full of memories.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: With the immediate and present data of our senses, we mingle a thousand
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: details out of our past experience." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 24
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Fr. p. 20).] To such an extent is this true that the immediate data of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: perception serve as a sign to bring much more to the mind. Psychological
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: experiments have conclusively proved that we never actually perceive all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that we imagine to be there. Hence arise illusions, examples of which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: may be easily thought of--incorrect proof-reading is one, while another
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: common one is the mistake of taking one person for another because of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: some similarity of dress. What is actually perceived is but a fraction
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of what we are looking at and acts normally as a suggestion for the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whole. Now, although it is true that, in practice, Perception and Memory
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are never found absolutely separate in their purity, yet it is necessary
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to distinguish them from one another absolutely in any investigation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of a psychological nature. If, instead of a perception impregnated
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with memory-images, nothing survived from the past, then we should have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "pure" perception, not coloured by anything in the individual's past
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: history, and so a kind of impersonal perception. However unreal it may
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: seem, such a perception is at the root of our knowledge of things and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: individual accidents are merely grafted on to this impersonal or "pure"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: perception. Just because philosophers have overlooked it, and because
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: they have failed to distinguish it from that which memory contributes to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it, they have regarded Perception as a kind of interior and subjective
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: vision, differing from Memory only by its greater intensity and not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: differing in nature. In reality, however, Perception and Memory differ
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fundamentally.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Our conscious perception is just our power of choice, reflected from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: things as though by a mirror, so that representation arises from the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: omission of that in the totality of matter which has no bearing on our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: needs and consequently no interest for us. "There is for images merely
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a difference of degree and not of kind between 'being' and 'being
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciously perceived.'" [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 30 (Fr. p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 25).] Consciousness--in regard to external perception--is explained by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this indeterminateness and this choice. "But there is in this necessary
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: poverty of conscious perception, something that is positive, that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: foretells spirit; it is, in the etymological sense of the word,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: discernment.'" [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 31 (Fr. p. 26).] The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: chief difficulty in dealing with the problems of Perception, is to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: explain "not how Perception arises, but how it is limited, since it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: should be the image of the whole and is in fact reduced to the image of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that which interests you." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 34 (Fr. p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 29).] We only make an insuperable difficulty if we imagine Perception
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to be a kind of photographic view of things, taken from a fixed point
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by that special apparatus which is called an organ of perception--a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: photograph which would then be developed in the brain-matter by some
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: unknown chemical and psychical process. "Everything happens as though
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: your perception were a result of the internal motions of the brain and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: issued in some sort from the cortical centres. It could not actually
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: come from them since the brain is an image like others, enveloped in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mass of other images, and it would be absurd that the container should
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: issue from the content. But since the structure of the brain is like
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the detailed plan of the movements among which you have the choice,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and since that part of the external images which appears to return upon
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: itself, in order to constitute perception, includes precisely all the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: points of the universe which these movements could affect, conscious
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: perception and cerebral movement are in strict correspondence. The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reciprocal dependence of these two terms is therefore simply due to the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fact that both are functions of a third, which is the indetermination of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the Will." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 35 (Fr. p. 29).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Moreover, we must recognize that the image is formed and perceived in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the object, not in the brain, even although it would seem that rays
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of light coming from a point P are perceived along the path of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sensori-motor processes in the brain and are afterwards projected into
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: P. There is not, however, an unextended image which forms itself in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness and then projects itself into the position P. Really,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the point P, and the rays which it emits, together with the retina
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and nervous elements affected in the process of perception, all form a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: single whole. The point P is an indispensable factor in this whole and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is really in P and not anywhere else that the image of P is formed
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and perceived.[Footnote: Cf. Matter and Memory, p. 37 (Fr p. 31), also
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: paper entitled Notre croyance a la loi de causalite in the Revue de
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: metaphysique et de morale, 1900, p. 658.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In the field of "pure" perception, that is to say, perception
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: unadulterated by the addition of memory-images, there can arise no image
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: without an object. "Sensation is essentially due to what is actually
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: present." [Footnote: Le Souvenir du present et la fausse reconnaissance,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 579 of Revue philosophique, Dec., 1908; also L'Energie spirituelle,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 141 (Mind-Energy).] Exactly how external stimuli, such as rays of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a certain speed and length, come to give us a certain image, e.g., the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sensation "red" or the sound of "middle C," we shall never understand.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "No trace of the movements themselves can be actually perceived in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sensation which translates them." [Footnote: Time and Free Will, pp.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 34-35 (Fr. p. 26).] We only make trouble by regarding sensations in an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: isolated manner and attempting to construct Perception from them. "Our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sensations are to our perceptions, that which the real action of our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: body is to its possible or virtual action." [Footnote: Matter and Memory,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 58 (Fr. p. 48).] Thus, everything happens as if the external images
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: were reflected by our body into surrounding space. This is why the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: surface of the body, which forms the common limit of the external and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: internal, is the only portion of space which is both perceived and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: felt. Just as external objects are perceived by me where they are, in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: themselves and not in me, so my affective states (e.g. pains--which are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: local, unavailing efforts) are experienced where they occur, in my body.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Consider the system of images which we term the "external world." My
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: body is one of them and around it is grouped the representation, i.e.,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: its eventual influence on others. Within it occurs affection, i.e., its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: actual effort upon itself. It is because of this distinction between
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: images and sensations that we affirm that the totality of perceived
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: images subsists, even if our body disappears, whereas we cannot
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: annihilate our body without destroying our sensations. In practice,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our "pure" perception is adulterated with affection, as well as with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: memories. To understand Perception, however, we must--as previously
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: insisted upon--study it with reference to action. It is false to suppose
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "that perception and sensation exist for their own sake; the philosopher
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ascribes to them an entirely speculative function," [Footnote: Matter
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and Memory, p. 311 (Fr p. 261).] a proceeding which gives rise to the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fallacies of Realism and Idealism.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: It has been said that the choice of perceptions from among images in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: general is the effect of a "discernment" which foreshadows spirit. But
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to touch the reality of spirit, we must place ourselves at the point
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: where an individual consciousness continues and retains the past in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a present, enriched by it.[Footnote: See Chapter VI on la duree.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time--True and False.] Perception we never meet in its pure state; it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is always mingled with memories. The rose has a different scent for you
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from that which it has for me, just because the scent of the rose bears
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with it all the memories of all the roses we have ever experienced, each
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of us individually.[Footnote: Time and Free Will, pp. 161-162 (Fr.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 124).] Memory, however mingled with Perception, is nevertheless
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fundamentally different in character.[Footnote: Le Souvenir du present
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: et la fausse reconnaissance, Revue philosophique, Dec., 1908, p. 580;
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: also L'Effort intellectuel, Revue philosophique, Jan., 1902, p. 23;
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: L'Energie spirituelle, pp. 141 and 197 (Mind-Energy).] "When we pass
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from 'pure' Perception to Memory, we definitely abandon matter for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: spirit." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 313 (Fr. p. 263).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: CHAPTER IV
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: MEMORY
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Definition--Two forms--memorizing power related to habit; recalling
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: power or "pure" memory. Is memory a function of the brain?--Pathological
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Phenomena. Memory something other than merely a function of the brain.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The "Box" theory--Memory records everything--Dreams--The well-balanced
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mind--Memory a manifestation of spirit.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The importance of Memory is recognized by all persons--whether
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: psychologists or not. At the present time there is a growing interest
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in systems of memory-training offered to the public, which aim at mental
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: efficiency as a means to success in life. Indeed, from the tone of some
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: advertisements seen in the press, one might be prompted to think that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Memory itself was the sole factor determining success in either a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: professional or a business career. Yet, although we are likely to regard
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this as a somewhat exaggerated statement, nevertheless we cannot deny
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander
