text: the very great importance of the power of Memory. How often, in everyday
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life, we hear people excuse themselves by remarking "My memory failed
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: me" or "played me false" or, more bluntly, "I forgot all about that."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Without doubt, Memory is a most vital factor, though not the only one
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in mental efficiency.[Footnote: The true ideal of mental efficiency must
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: include power of Will as well as of Memory.] It is an element in mental
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life which puzzles both the specialist in psychology and the layman.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "What is this wonderfully subtle power of mind?" "How do we remember?"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Even the mind, untrained in psychological investigation, cannot help
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: asking such questions in moments of reflection; but for the psychologist
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: they are questions of very vital significance in his science. For
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson, as psychologist, Memory is naturally, a subject of great
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: importance. We must note, however, that for Bergson, as metaphysician,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it plays an even more important role, since his study of Memory and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conclusions as to its nature lead him on to a discussion of the relation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of soul and body, spirit and matter. His second large work, which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: appeared in 1896, bears the title Matiere et Memoire. For him, Memory
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is a pivot on which turns a whole scheme of relationships--material
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and spiritual. He wrote in 1910 a new introduction for the English
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Translation of this work. He there says that "among all the facts
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: capable of throwing light on the psycho-physiological relation, those
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which concern Memory, whether in the normal or the pathological state,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: hold a privileged position." [Footnote: Introduction to Matter and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Memory, p. xii.] Let us then, prior to passing on to the consideration
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the problem of the relation of soul and body, examine what Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: has to say on the subject of Memory.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: At the outset, we may define Memory as the return to consciousness of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: some experience, accompanied by the awareness that it has been present
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: earlier at a definite time and place.[Footnote: The above is to be taken
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as a definition of the normal memory. In a subtle psychological analysis
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in the paper entitled Le Souvenir du present et la fausse reconnaissance
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in L'Energie spirituelle, pp. 117-161 (Mind-Energy), Bergson considers
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: cases of an abnormal or fictitious memory, coinciding with perception in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rather a strange manner. This does not, however, affect the validity
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the above definition.] Bergson first of all draws attention to a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: distinction between two different forms of Memory, the nature of which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: will be best brought out by considering two examples. We are fond of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: giving to children or young persons at school selections from the plays
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Shakespeare, "to be learned by heart," as we say. We praise the boy
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or girl who can repeat a long passage perfectly, and we regard that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: scholar as gifted with a good memory. To illustrate the second type of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: case, suppose a question to be put to that boy asking him what he saw on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the last half-holiday when he took a ramble in the country. He may, or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: may not, be able to tell us much of his adventures on that occasion,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for whatever he can recall is due to a mental operation of a different
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: character from that which enabled him to learn his lesson. There is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: here no question of learning by rote, of memorizing, but of capacity to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: recall to mind a past experience. The boy who is clever at memorizing a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: passage from Shakespeare may not have a good memory at all for recalling
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: past events. To understand why this is so we must examine these two
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: forms of Memory more closely and refer to Bergson's own words: "I study
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a lesson, and in order to learn it by heart I read it a first time,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: accentuating every line; I then repeat it a certain number of times. At
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: each repetition there is progress; the words are more and more linked
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: together, and at last make a continuous whole. When that moment comes,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is said that I know my lesson by heart, that it is imprinted on my
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: memory. I consider now how the lesson has been learnt and picture to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: myself the successive phases of the process. Each several reading then
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: recurs to me with its own individuality. It is distinguished from those
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which preceded or followed it, by the place which it occupied in time;
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in short, each reading stands out before my mind as a definite event in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: my history. Again it will be said that these images are recollections,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that they are imprinted on my Memory. The same words then are used in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: both cases. Do they mean the same thing? The memory of the lesson which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is remembered, in the sense of learned by heart, has ALL the marks of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a habit. Like a habit, it is acquired by the repetition of the same
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: effort. Like every habitual bodily exercise, it is stored up in a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mechanism which is set in motion as a whole by an initial impulse, in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a closed system of automatic movements, which succeed each other in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: same order and together take the same length of time. The memory of each
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: several reading, on the contrary, has NONE of the marks of a habit, it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is like an event in my life; it is a case of spontaneous recollection as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: distinct from mere learnt recollection. Now a learnt recollection passes
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: out of time in the measure that the lesson is better known; it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: becomes more and more impersonal, more and more foreign to our past
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, pp. 89-90 (Fr. pp. 75-76).] This
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: quotation makes clear that of these two forms of Memory, it is the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: power of spontaneous recollection which is Memory par excellence and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: constitutes "real" Memory. The other, to which psychologists usually
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have devoted most of their attention in discussing the problem of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Memory, is habit interpreted as Memory, rather than Memory itself.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Having thus made clear this valuable and fundamental distinction--"one
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the best things in Bergson" [Footnote: Bertrand Russell's remark in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: his Philosophy of Bergson, p. 7.]--and having shown that in practical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life the automatic memory necessarily plays an important part, often
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inhibiting "pure" Memory, Bergson proceeds to examine and criticize
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: certain views of Memory itself, and endeavours finally to demonstrate to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: us what he himself considers it to be.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: He takes up the cudgels to attack the view which aims at blending Memory
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with Perception, as being of like kind. Memory, he argues, must be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: distinguished from Perception, however much we admit (and rightly)
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that memories enter into and colour all our perceptions. They are quite
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: different in their nature. A remembrance is the representation of an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: absent object. We distinguish between hearing a faint tap at the door,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and the faint memory of a loud one. We cannot admit the validity of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the statement that there is only a difference of intensity between
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Perception and Recollection. "As our perception of a present object
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is something of that object itself, our representation of the absent
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: object, as in Memory, must be a phenomenon of quite other order than
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Perception, since between presence and absence there are no degrees, no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intermediate stages." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 315 (Fr. p. 264).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: If we maintain that recollection is merely a weakened form of Perception
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we must note the consequences of such a thesis. "If recollection is only
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a weakened Perception, inversely, Perception must be something like an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intenser Memory. Now, the germ of English Idealism is to be found here.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: This Idealism consists in finding only a difference of degree and not of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: kind, between the reality of the object perceived, and the ideality
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the object conceived." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 318 (Fr.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 267).] The maintenance of such a doctrine involves the further
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: remarkable contention that "we construct matter from our own interior
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: states and that perception is only a true hallucination." [Footnote:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Matter and Memory, p 318 (Fr. p. 267).] Such a theory will not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: harmonize with the experienced difference between Perceptions and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Memories.[Footnote: Le Souvenir du present et la fausse reconnaissance,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Revue philosophique, Dec., 1908, p. 568; also L'Energie spirituelle
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Mind-Energy).] We do not mistake the perception of a slight sound for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the recollection of a loud noise, as has already been remarked. The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness of a recollection "never occurs as a weak state which we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: try to relegate to the past so soon as we become aware of its weakness.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: How indeed, unless we already possess the representation of a past,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: previously lived, could we relegate to it the less intense psychical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: states, when it would be so simple to set them alongside of strong
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: states as a present experience more confused, beside a present
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: experience more distinct?" [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 319 (Fr. p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 268).] The truth is that Memory does not consist in a regression from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the present into the past, but on the contrary, in a progress from the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: past to the present. Memory is radically distinct from Perception, in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: its character.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson then passes on to discuss other views of Memory, and in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: particular, those which deal with the nature of Memory and its relation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to the brain. It is stated dogmatically by some that Memory is a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: function of the brain. Others claim, in opposition to this, that Memory
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is something other than a function of the brain. Between two such
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: statements as these, compromise or reconciliation is obviously
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: impossible. It is then for experience to decide between these two
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conflicting views. This empirical appeal Bergson does not shirk. He has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: made a most comprehensive and intensive study of pathological phenomena
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: relating to the mental malady known as aphasia. This particular type of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: disorder belongs to a whole class of mental diseases known as amnesia.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Now amnesia (in Greek, "forgetfulness") is literally any loss or defect
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the Memory. Aphasia (in Greek "absence of speech") is a total or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: partial loss of the power of speech, either in its spoken or written
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: form. The term covers the loss of the power of expression by spoken
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: words, but is often extended to include both word-deafness, i.e., the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: misunderstanding of what is said, and word-blindness--the inability to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: read words. An inability to execute the movements necessary to express
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: oneself, either by gesture, writing, or speech, is styled "motor
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: aphasia," to distinguish it from the inability to understand
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: familiar gestures and written or spoken words, which is known as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "sensory-aphasia." The commonest causes of this disease are lesions,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: affecting the special nerve centres, due to haemorrhage or the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: development of tumours, being in the one case rapid, in the other a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: gradual development. Of course any severe excitement, fright or illness,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: involving a disturbance of the normal circulation in the cerebral
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: centres, may produce asphasia. During the war, it has been one of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: afflictions of a large number of the victims of "shell-shock." But,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whatever be the cause, the patient is reduced mentally to an elementary
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: state, resembling that of a child, and needs re-educating in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: elements of language.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Now, from his careful study of the pathological phenomena, manifested in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: these cases, Bergson draws some very important conclusions in regard
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to the nature of Memory and its relation to the brain. In 1896, when he
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: brought out his work Matiere et Memoire, in Paris, the general view
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: was against his conclusions and his opinions were ridiculed. By 1910, a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: marked change had come about and he was able to refer to this in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: new introduction.[Footnote: See Bibliography, p. 158.] His view was
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: no longer considered paradoxical. The conception of aphasia, once
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: classical, universally admitted, believed to be unshakeable, had been
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: considerably shaken in that period of fourteen years. Localization,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and reference to centres would not, it was found, explain things
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sufficiently.[Footnote: The work of Pierre Janet was largely influential
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: also in bringing about this change of view.] This involved a too rigid
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and mechanical conception of the brain as a mere "box," and Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: attacks it very forcibly under the name of "the box theory." "All the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: arguments," he says, "from fact which may be invoked in favour of a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: probable accumulation of memories in the cortical substance, are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: drawn from local disorders of memory. But if recollections were really
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: deposited in the brain, to definite gaps in memory characteristic
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: lesions of the brain would correspond. Now in those forms of amnesia in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which a whole period of our past existence, for example, is abruptly and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: entirely obliterated from memory, we do not observe any precise cerebral
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: lesion; and on the contrary, in those disorders of memory where cerebral
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: localization is distinct and certain, that is to say, in the different
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: types of aphasia, and in the diseases of visual or auditory recognition,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we do not find that certain definite recollections are, as it were, torn
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from their seat, but that it is the whole faculty of remembering that is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: more or less diminished in vitality, as if the subject had more or less
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: difficulty in bringing his recollections into contact with the present
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: situation." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 315 (Fr. pp. 264-265).] But
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as it is a fact that the past survives under two distinct forms, viz.,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "motor mechanisms" and "independent recollections," we find that this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: explains why "in all cases where a lesion of the brain attacks a certain
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: category of recollections, the affected recollections do not resemble
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: each other by all belonging to the same period, or by any logical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: relationship to one another, but simply in that they are all auditive or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: all visual or all motor. That which is damaged appears to be the various
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sensorial or motor areas, or more often still, those appendages which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: permit of their being set going from within the cortex rather than the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: recollections themselves." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 317 (Fr. p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 266).] Going even further than this, by the study of the recognition of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: words, and of sensory-aphasia, Bergson shows that "recognition is in no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: way affected by a mechanical awakening of memories that are asleep in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the brain. It implies, on the contrary, a more or less high degree of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: tension in consciousness, which goes to fetch pure recollections in pure
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: memory, in order to materialize them progressively, by contact with the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: present perception." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 317 (Fr. p. 266).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In the face of all this mass of evidence and thoroughness of argument
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which Bergson brings forward, we are led to conclude that Memory is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: indeed something other than a function of the brain. Criticizing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Wundt's view,[Footnote: As expressed in his Grundzuge der physiologische
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: psychologie, vol. I., pp. 320-327. See Matter and Memory, p. 164 (Fr.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 137).]Bergson contends that no trace of an image can remain in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: substance of the brain and no centre of apperception can exist. "There
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is not in the brain a region in which memories congeal and accumulate.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The alleged destruction of memories by an injury to the brain is but
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a break in the continuous progress by which they actualize
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: themselves." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 160 (Fr. p. 134).] It is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: then futile to ask in what spot past memories are stored. To look for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: them in any place would be as meaningless as asking to see traces of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: telephonic message upon the telephone wire.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "Memory," it has been said, "is a faculty which loses nothing and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: records everything." [Footnote: Ball, quoted by Rouillard, Les Amnesies,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Paris, 1885, p. 25; Matter and Memory, p. 201 (Fr. p. 168).] This is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: only too true, although normally we do not recognize it. But we can
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: never be sure that we have absolutely forgotten anything. Illness,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: producing delirium, may provoke us to speak of things we had thought
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: were gone beyond recall and which perhaps we even wish were beyond
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: recall. A somnambulistic state or even a dream may show us memory
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: extending far further back than we could ordinarily imagine. The facing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of death in battle, we know, recalls to many, with extreme vividness,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: scenes of early childhood which they had deemed long since forgotten.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "There is nothing," says Bergson, "more instructive in this regard than
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: what happens in cases of sudden suffocation--in men drowned or hanged.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The man, when brought to life again, states that he saw in a very short
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: time all the forgotten events of his life, passing before him with great
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rapidity, with their smallest circumstances, and in the very order in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which they occurred." [Footnote: La Perception du Changement, pp.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 30-31, and Matter and Memory, p 200 (Fr p 168).] Hence we can never be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: absolutely sure that we have forgotten anything although at any given
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: time we may be unable to recall it to mind. There is an unconscious
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: memory.[Footnote: Cf. Samuel Butler's Unconscious Memory.] Speaking
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the profound and yet undeniable reality of the unconscious, Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: says,[Footnote: Matter and Memory, pp 181-182 (Fr. pp. 152-153).
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: See also Le Souvenir du present et la fausse reconnaissance, Revue
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophique, Dec., 1908, p. 592, and L'Energie spirituelle, pp.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 159-161 (Mind-Energy).] "Our unwillingness to conceive unconscious
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: psychical states, is due, above all, to the fact that we hold
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness to be the essential property of psychical states, so
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that a psychical state cannot, it seems, cease to be conscious without
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ceasing to exist. But if consciousness is but the characteristic note
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the present, that is to say, of the actually lived, in short, of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the active, then that which does not act may cease to belong to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness without therefore ceasing to exist in some manner. In
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: other words, in the psychological domain, consciousness may not be the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: synonym of existence, but only of real action or of immediate efficacy;
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: limiting thus the meaning of the term, we shall have less difficulty in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: representing to ourselves a psychical state which is unconscious, that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is to say, ineffective. Whatever idea we may frame of consciousness in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: itself, such as it would be if it could work untrammelled, we cannot
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: deny that in a being which has bodily functions, the chief office
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of consciousness is to preside over action and to enlighten choice.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Therefore it throws light on the immediate antecedents of the decision
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and on those past recollections which can usefully combine with it; all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: else remains in shadow." But we have no more right to say that the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: past effaces itself as soon as perceived than to suppose that material
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: objects cease to exist when we cease to perceive them. Memory, to use

text: The following is a brief summary of the view there set forth. Memories,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and only memories, weave the web of our dreams. They are "such stuff as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: dreams are made on." Often we do not recognize them. They may be very
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: old memories, forgotten during waking hours, drawn from the most
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: obscure depths of our past, or memories of objects we have perceived
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: distractedly, almost unconsciously, while awake. They may be fragments
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of broken memories, composing an incoherent and unrecognizable whole.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In a waking state our memories are closely connected with our present
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: situation (unless we be given to day-dreams!). In an animal memory
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: serves to recall to him the advantageous or injurious consequences
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which have formerly arisen in a like situation, and so aids his present
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: action. In man, memory forms a solid whole, a pyramid whose point is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inserted precisely into our present action. But behind the memories
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which are involved in our occupations, there are others, thousands of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: others, stored below the scene illuminated by consciousness. "Yes,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: I believe indeed," says Bergson, "that all our past life is there,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: preserved even to the most infinitesimal details, and that we forget
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: nothing and that all that we have ever felt, perceived, thought, willed,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from the first awakening of our consciousness, survives indestructibly."

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: only those were admitted which bore on the present situation. Now, in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sleep, more vague images occupy my vision, more indecisive sounds
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reach my ear, more indistinct touches come to my body, and more vague
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sensations come from my internal organs. Hence those memories which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: can assimilate themselves to some element in this vague mass of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: very indistinct sensations manage to get through. When such union is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: effected, between memory and sensation, we have a dream.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In order that a recollection should be brought to mind, it is necessary
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that it should descend from the height of pure memory to the precise
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: point where action is taking place. Such a power is the mark of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: well-balanced mind, pursuing a via media between impulsiveness on the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: one hand, and dreaminess on the other. "The characteristic of the man of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: action," says Bergson in this connexion, "is the promptitude with which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by the immediate reaction which prolongs it, is the mark of the lower
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: animals; the man who proceeds in this way is a man of impulse. But he
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: who lives in the past, for the mere pleasure of living there, and in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whom recollections emerge into the light of consciousness, without any
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: advantage for the present situation, is hardly better fitted for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: action; here we have no man of impulse, but a dreamer. Between these two

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: involved in intellectual effort. There is at first, he shows, something
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: conceived quite generally, an idea vague and abstract, a schema which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: image. Various images endeavour to fit themselves into the schema, or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the schema may adapt itself to the reception of the images. These
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intellectual effort.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Memory then, Bergson wishes us to realize, in response to his treatment
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of it, is no mere function of the brain; it is something infinitely more
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: stored in the brain like letters in a filing cabinet, and all our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: importance when we come to investigate the problem of the relation of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: soul and body. For "Memory must be, in principle, a power absolutely
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the phenomenon of Memory that we may come into touch with it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: experimentally." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, p. 81 (Fr. p. 68).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and matter." [Footnote: Matter and Memory, Introduction, p. xii.] "A

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: CHAPTER V
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: THE RELATION OF SOUL AND BODY
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The hypothesis of Psycho-physical Parallelism--Not to be accepted
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: uncritically--Bergson opposes it, and shows the hypothesis to rest on a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: confusion of terms. Bergson against Epiphenomenalism--Soul-life unique
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and wider than the brain--Telepathy, subconscious action and psychical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: research--Souls and survival.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: For philosophy in general, and for psychology in particular, the problem
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the relation of soul and body has prime significance, and moreover,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is a problem with which each of us is acquainted intimately
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and practically, even if we know little or nothing of the academic
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: discussions, or of the technical terms representing various views. It is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: very frequently the terminology which turns the plain man away from the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consideration of philosophical problems; but he has some conception,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: however crude it may be, of his soul or his mind and of his body.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: These terms are familiar to him, but the sight of a phrase like
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "psycho-physical parallelism" rather daunts him. Really, it stands for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: quite a simple thing, and is just the official label used to designate
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the theory commonly held by scientific men of all kinds, to describe the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: relation of soul and body. Put more precisely, it is just the assertion
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that brain and consciousness work on parallel lines.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson does not accept the hypothesis of psycho-physical parallelism.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is to be found wholly in the corresponding cerebral state. It is true
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that we should not find many physiologists or philosophers who would
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: relation between two terms is equal to one of them. This involves

text: contradiction and Realism then crosses over to the other system of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: notation. It cannot do without Idealism: science itself oscillates from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: the one system to the other. We cannot admit Parallelism as a dogma--as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: a metaphysical truth--however useful it may be as a working hypothesis.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: Bergson then proceeds to state and to criticize some of the mischievous
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ideas which arise from Parallelism. There is the idea of a brain-soul,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of a spot where the soul lives or where the brain thinks--which we have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: not quite abandoned since Descartes named the pineal gland as the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: seat of the soul. Then there is the false idea that all causality is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mechanistic and that there is nothing in the universe which is not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mathematically calculable. There is the confusion of representations
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and of things. There is the false notion that we may argue that if two
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: wholes are bound together there must be an equivalent relation of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: parts. Bergson points out in this connexion that the absence or the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: presence of a screw can stop a machine or keep it going, but the parts
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the screw do not correspond to the parts of the machine. In his new
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: introduction to Matiere et Memoire, he said, "There is a close connexion
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: between a state of consciousness and the brain: this we do not dispute.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: But there is also a close connexion between a coat and the nail on which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it hangs, for if the nail is pulled out the coat falls to the ground.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Shall we say then that the shape of the nail gives us the shape of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the coat or in any way corresponds to it? No more are we entitled to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conclude because the psychical fact is hung on to a cerebral state
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that there is any parallelism between the two series psychical and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: physiological." [Footnote: There must be an awkward misprint "physical"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for "psychical" in the English translation, p. xi.] Our observation and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: experience, and science itself, strictly speaking, do not allow us to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: assert more than that there exists a certain CORRESPONDENCE
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: between brain and consciousness. The psychical and the physical are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inter-dependent but not parallel.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson however has more to assert than merely the inadequacy and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: falsity of Parallelism or Epiphenomenalism. This last theory merely
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: adds consciousness to physical facts as a kind of phosphorescent
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: gleam, resembling, in Bergson's words, a "streak of light following the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement of a match rubbed along a wall in the dark." [Footnote: L'Ame
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: et le Corps, pp. 12-13, in Le Materialisme actuel, or pp. 35-36 of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: L'Energie spirituelle (Mind-Energy).] He maintains, as against all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this, the irreducibility of the mental, our utter inability to interpret
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness in terms of anything else, the life of the soul being
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: unique. He further claims that this psychical life is wider and richer
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: than we commonly suppose. The brain is the organ of attention to life.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: What was said in regard to memory and the brain is applicable to all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our mental life. The mind or soul is wider than the brain in every
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: direction, and the brain's activity corresponds to no more than an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: infinitesimal part of the activity of the mind. [Footnote: L'Ame et le
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Corps, Le Materialisme actuel, p. 45, L'Energie spirituelle, p. 61.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: 1913, where he remarked, "The cerebral life is to the mental life
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: what the movements of the baton of a conductor are to the symphony."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: The Times, May 29, 1913.] Such a remark contains fruitful
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: suggestions to all engaged in Psychical Research, and to all persons
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: interested in the fascinating study of telepathy. Bergson is of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: opinion that we are far less definitely cut off from each other, soul
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from soul, than we are body from body. "It is space," he says, "which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: creates multiplicity and distinction. It is by their bodies that the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: demonstrated that human consciousness is partially independent of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: human brain, since the cerebral life represents only a small part of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mental life, it is very possible that the separation between the various
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: human consciousnesses or souls, may not be so radical as it seems to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be." [Footnote: The Times, May 29, 1913.] There may be, he suggests,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in the psychical world, a process analogous to what is known in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: investigation of telepathy, he pointed out that it was probable, or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sub-conscious influence of soul on soul, but too feebly to be noticed
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by active consciousness, or it was neutralized by certain obstacles.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We have no right to deny its possibility on the plea of its being
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: supernatural, or against natural law, for our ignorance does not entitle
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: us to say what may be natural or not. If telepathy does not square at
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: especially will this be so if our notion of the relation of soul and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: body be based on Parallelism. We must overcome this prejudice and seek
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to make others set it aside. Telepathy and the sub-conscious mental life
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: combine to make us realize the wonder of the soul. It is not spatial,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is spiritual. Bergson insists strongly on the unity of our conscious
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life. Merely associationist theories are vicious in this respect: they
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: try to resolve the whole into parts, and then neglect the whole in their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: concentration on the parts. All psychological investigation incurs this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: risk of dealing with abstractions. "Psychology, in fact, proceeds like
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: all the other sciences by analysis. It resolves the self which has been
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: given to it at first in a simple intuition, into sensations, feelings,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ideas, etc., which it studies separately. It substitutes then for the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: self a series of elements which form the facts of psychology. But are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: these elements really parts? That is the whole question, and it is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: because it has been evaded that the problem of human personality has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: so often been stated in insoluble terms." [Footnote: Introduction to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Metaphysics, p. 21.] "Personality cannot be composed of psychical states
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: even if there be added to them a kind of thread for the purpose of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: joining the states together." [Footnote: Introduction to Metaphysics,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 25.] We shall never make the soul fit into a category or succeed in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: applying concepts to our inner life. The life of the soul is wider than
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the brain and wider than all intellectual constructions or moulds we may
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: attempt to form. It is a creative force capable of producing novelty in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the world: it creates actions and can, in addition, create itself.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Philosophy shows us "the life of the body just where it really is, on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the road that leads to the life of the spirit"; our powers of sense
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: impression and of intelligence are both instruments in the service of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the will. With a little will one can do much if one places the will in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the right direction. For this force of will which is the essence of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the soul or personality has these exceptional characteristics, that its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intensity depends on its direction, and that its quality may become the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: creator of quantity. [Footnote: See the lectures La Nature de l'Ame.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The brain and the body in general are instruments of the soul. The brain
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: orients the mind toward action, it is the point of attachment between
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the spirit and its material environment. It is like the point of a knife
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to the blade--it enables it to penetrate into the realm of action or,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to give another of Bergson's metaphors, it is like the prow of the ship,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: enabling the soul to penetrate the billows of reality. Yet, for all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that, it limits and confines the life of the spirit; it narrows vision
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as do the blinkers which we put on horses. We must, however, abandon the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: notion of any rigid and determined parallelism between soul and body and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: accustom ourselves to the fact that the life of the mind is wider
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: than the limits of cerebral activity. And further, there is this to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consider--"The more we become accustomed to this idea of a consciousness
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which overflows the organ we call the brain, then the more natural and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: probable we find the hypothesis that the soul survives the body. For
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: were the mental exactly modelled on the cerebral, we might have to admit
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that consciousness must share the fate of the body and die with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it." [Footnote: New York Times, Sept. 27, 1914.] "But the destiny of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness is not bound up with the destiny of cerebral matter."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 285 (Fr. p. 293).] "Although the

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: yet it leaves the way open for a belief in a future life and creates a

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: (Fr. p. 294). In Life and Consciousness he says we may admit that in man

text: at any rate "Consciousness pursues its path beyond this earthly life"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 29, and to L'Ame et le Corps, in the same vol., p. 63.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The great error of the spiritual philosophers has been the idea that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by isolating the spiritual life from all the rest, by suspending it in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: space, as high as possible above the earth, they were placing it beyond
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: attack; as if they were not, thereby, simply exposing it to be taken as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: an effect of mirage! Certainly they are right to believe in the absolute
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reality of the person and in his independence of matter: but science is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there which shows the inter-dependence of conscious life and cerebral
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: activity. When a strong instinct assures the probability of personal
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: survival, they are right not to close their ears to its voice; but if
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there exist "souls" capable of an independent life, whence do they come?
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: When, how, and why do they enter into this body which we see arise quite
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: naturally from a mixed cell derived from the bodies of its two parents?
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 283 (Fr. p. 291).] At the close of

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: CHAPTER VI
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: TIME--TRUE AND FALSE
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Our ordinary conception of Time false because it is spatial and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: homogeneous--Real Time (la duree) not spatial or homogeneous--Flow of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness a qualitative multiplicity--The real self and the external
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: self. La duree and the life of the self--No repetition--Personality and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the accumulation of experience-Change and la duree as vital elements in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the universe.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: For any proper understanding of Bergson's thought, it is necessary to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: grasp his views regarding Time, for they are fundamental factors in his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophy and serve to distinguish it specially from that of previous
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thinkers. It is interesting to note however, in passing, that Dr. Ward,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in his Realm of Ends, claims to have anticipated Bergson's view of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Concrete Time. In discussing the relation of such Time to the conception
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of God, he says, "I think I may fairly claim to have anticipated him
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Bergson) to some extent. In 1886 I had written a long paragraph on this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: topic." [Footnote: See The Realm of Ends' foot-note on pp. 306-7. Ward
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is referring to his famous article in the Encyclopaedia Britannica,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: eleventh edition, Psychology, p. 577 (now revised and issued in book
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: form as Psychological Principles).] Be this as it may, no philosopher
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: has made so much of this view of Time as Bergson. One might say it is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the corner-stone of his philosophy, for practically the whole of it is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: built upon his conception of Time. His first large work, Essai sur les
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: donnees immediates de la conscience, or, to give it its better title, in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: English, Time and Free Will, appeared in 1889.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Our ordinary conception of Time, that which comes to us from the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: physical sciences, is, Bergson maintains, a false one. It is false
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: because so far from being temporal in character, it is spatial. We look
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: upon space as a homogeneous medium without boundaries; yet we look on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time too, as just such another medium, homogeneous and unlimited. Now
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: here is an obvious difficulty, for since homogeneity consists in being
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: without qualities, it is difficult to see how one homogeneity can be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: distinguished from another. This difficulty is usually avoided by the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: assertion that homogeneity takes two forms, one in which its contents
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: co-exist, and another in which they follow one another. Space, then,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we say, is that homogeneous medium in which we are aware of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: side-by-sideness, Time--that homogeneous medium in which we are aware
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of an element of succession. But this surely we are not entitled to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: maintain, for we are then distinguishing two supposed homogeneities
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by asserting a difference of quality in them. To do so is to take away
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: homogeneity. We must think again and seek a way out of this difficulty.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Let us admit space to be a homogeneous medium without bounds. Then every
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: homogeneous medium without bounds must be space. What, then, becomes of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time?--for on this showing, Time becomes space. Yes, says Bergson, that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is so, for our common view of Time is a false one, being really a hybrid
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conception, a spurious concept due to the illicit introduction of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: idea of space, and to our application of the notion of space, which is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: applicable to physical objects, to states of consciousness, to which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is really inapplicable. Objects occupying space are marked out as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: external to one another, but this cannot be said of conscious states.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Yet, in our ordinary speech and conventional view of things, we think
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of conscious states as separated from one another and as spread out like
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "things," in a fictitious, homogeneous medium to which we give the name
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time. Bergson says, "At any rate, we cannot finally admit two forms of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the homogeneous, Time and Space, without first seeking whether one
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of them cannot be reduced to the other. Now, externality is the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: distinguishing mark of things which occupy space, while states of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness are not essentially external to one another and become so
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: only by being spread out in Time regarded as a homogeneous medium. If,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: then, one of these two supposed forms of the homogeneous, viz., Time and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Space, is derived from the other, we can surmise a priori that the idea
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of space is the fundamental datum. Time, conceived under the form of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: an unbounded and homogeneous medium, is nothing but the ghost of space,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: haunting the reflective consciousness." [Footnote: Time and Free Will,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 98 (Fr. p. 75).] Bergson remarks that Kant's great mistake was to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: take Time as a homogeneous medium. [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 232
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Having asserted the falsity of the view of Time ordinarily held,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson proceeds to make clear to us his view of what Real Time is--an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: what is one of the most difficult sections of his philosophy. An initial
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: difficulty meets us in giving a definite name to the Time which Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: regards as so real, as opposed to the spatial falsity, masquerading as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time, whose true colours he has revealed. In the original French text
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson employs the term duree to convey his meaning. But for the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: translation of this into English there is no term which will suffice and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
