text: which will adequately convey to the reader, without further exposition,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the wealth of meaning intended to be conveyed. "Duration" is usually
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: employed by translators as the nearest approach possible in English. The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inadequacy of language is never more keenly felt than in dealing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with fundamental problems of thought. Its chief mischief is its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: all-too-frequent ambiguity. In the following remarks the original French
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: term la duree will be used in preference to the English word "Duration."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The distinction between the false Time and true Time may be regarded
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as a distinction between mathematical Time and living Time, or between
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: abstract and concrete Time. This living, concrete Time is that true Time
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of which Bergson endeavours to give us a conception as la duree. He has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: criticized the abstract mathematical Time, his attack having been made
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to open up the way for a treatment of what he really considers Time to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be. Now, from the arguments previously mentioned, it follows that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time, Real Time, which is radically different from space, cannot be any
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: homogeneous medium. It is heterogeneous in character. We are aware of it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in relation to ourselves, for it has reference not to the existence of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a multiplicity of material objects in space, but to a multiplicity of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a quite different nature, entirely non-spatial, viz., that of conscious
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: states. Being non-spatial, such a multiplicity cannot be composed of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: elements which are external to one another as are the objects existing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in space. States of consciousness are not in any way external to one
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: another. Indeed, they interpenetrate to such a degree that even the use
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the word "state" is apt to be misleading. As we saw in the chapter on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The Reality of Change, there can be strictly no states of consciousness,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for consciousness is not static but dynamic. Language and conventional
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: figures of speech, of which the word "state" itself is a good example,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: serve to cut up consciousness artificially, but, in reality, it is,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as William James termed it, "a stream" and herein lies the essence of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson's duree--the Real as opposed to the False Time. "Pure Duration"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (la duree pure), he says, "is the form which the succession of our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conscious states assumes when our Ego lets itself live, when it refrains
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from separating its present state from its former states. For this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: purpose, it need not be entirely absorbed in the passing sensation or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: idea, for then, on the contrary, it would no longer 'endure.' Nor
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: need it forget its former states; it is enough that in recalling these
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: states, it does not set them alongside its actual state as one point
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: alongside another, but forms both the past and the present states
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: into an organic whole, as happens when we recall the notes of a tune,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: melting, so to speak, into one another. Might it not be said that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: even if these notes succeed one another, yet, we perceive them in one
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: another, and that their totality may be compared to a living being whose
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: parts, although distinct, permeate one another just because they are so
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: closely connected?" [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 100 (Fr. p. 76).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Such a duration is Real Time. Unfortunately, we, obsessed by the idea of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: space, introduce it unwittingly and set our states of consciousness side
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by side in such a way as to perceive them alongside one another; in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a word, we project them into space and we express duree in terms of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: extensity and succession thus takes the form of a continuous line or a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: chain--the parts of which touch without interpenetrating one another.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 100 (Fr. p. 76).] Thus is brought to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: birth that mongrel form, that hybrid conception of False Time criticized
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: above. Real Time, la duree, is not, however, susceptible like False
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time to measurement, for it is, strictly speaking, not quantitative in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: character, but is rather a qualitative multiplicity. "Real Duration (la
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: duree reele) is just what has always been called Time, but it is Time
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: perceived as indivisible." [Footnote: La Perception du Changement, p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 26. Cf. the whole of the Second Lecture.] Certainly pure consciousness
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: does not perceive Time as a sum of units of duration, for, left to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: itself, it has no means and even no reason to measure Time, but a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: feeling which lasted only half the number of days, for example, would
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: no longer be the same feeling for it. It is true that when we give this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: feeling a certain name, when we treat it as a thing, we believe that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we can diminish its duration by half, for example, and also halve the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: duration of all the rest of our history. It seems that it would still
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be the same life only on a reduced scale. But we forget that states
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of consciousness are processes and not things; that they are alive
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and therefore constantly changing, and that, in consequence, it is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: impossible to cut off a moment from them without making them poorer by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the loss of some impression and thus altering their quality. [Footnote:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time and Free Will, p. 196 (Fr. p. 150).] La duree appears as a "wholly
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: qualitative multiplicity, an absolute heterogeneity of elements which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: pass over into one another." [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 229 (Fr.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. 176).] Such a time cannot be measured by clocks or dials but only
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by conscious beings, for "it is the very stuff of which life and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness are made." Intellect does not grasp Real Time--we can
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: only have an intuition of it. "We do not think Real Time--but we live it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: because life transcends intellect."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In order to bring out the distinctly qualitative character of such a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conception of Time, Bergson says, "When we hear a series of blows of a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: hammer, the sounds form an indivisible melody in so far as they are pure
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sensations, and here again give rise to a dynamic progress; but, knowing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that the same objective cause is at work, we cut up this progress into
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: phases which we then regard as identical; and this multiplicity
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of elements no longer being conceivable except by being set out in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: space--since they have now become identical--we are, necessarily, led
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to the idea of a homogeneous Time, the symbolical image of la duree."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 125 (Fr. pp. 94-95).] "Whilst I am
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: writing these lines," he continues, "the hour strikes on a neighbouring
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: clock, but my inattentive ear does not perceive it until several strokes
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have made themselves heard. Hence, I have not counted them and yet I
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: only have to turn my attention backwards, to count up the four strokes
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which have already sounded, and add them to those which I hear. If,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: then, I question myself carefully on what has just taken place, I
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: perceive that the first four sounds had struck my ear and even affected
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: my consciousness, but that the sensations produced by each one of them,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: instead of being set side by side, had melted into one another in such
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a way as to give the whole a peculiar quality, to make a kind of musical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: phrase out of it. In order, then, to estimate retrospectively, the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: number of strokes sounded, I tried to reconstruct this phrase in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thought; my imagination made one stroke, then two, then three, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as long as it did not reach the exact number, four, my feeling, when
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consulted, was qualitatively different. It had thus ascertained, in its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: own way, the succession of four strokes, but quite otherwise than by a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: process of addition and without bringing in the image of a juxtaposition
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of distinct terms. In a word, the number of strokes was perceived as a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: quality and not as a quantity; it is thus that la duree is presented to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: immediate consciousness and it retains this form so long as it does
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: not give place to a symbolical representation, derived from extensity."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: Time and Free Will, pp. 127-8 (Fr. pp. 96-97).] In these
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: words Bergson endeavours to drive home his contention that la duree is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: essentially qualitative. He is well aware of the results of "the breach
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: between quality and quantity," between true duration and pure extensity.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: He sees its implications in regard to vital problems of the self,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of causality and of freedom. Its specific bearing on the problems of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: freedom and causality we shall discuss in the following chapter. As
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: regards the self, Bergson recognizes that we have much to gain by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: keeping up the illusion through which we make our conscious states share
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in the reciprocal externality of outer things, because this distinctness
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and solidification enables us to give them fixed names in spite of their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: instability, and distinct names in spite of their interpenetration.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Above all it enables us to objectify them, to throw them out into the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: current of social life. But just for this very reason we are in danger
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of living our lives superficially and of covering up our real self.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We are generally content with what is but a shadow of the real self,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: projected into space. Consciousness, goaded on by an insatiable desire
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to separate, substitutes the symbol for the reality or perceives the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reality only through the symbol. As the self thus refracted and thereby
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: broken in pieces, is much better adapted to the requirements of social
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life in general, and of language in particular, consciousness prefers it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and gradually loses sight of the fundamental self which is a qualitative
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: multiplicity of conscious states flowing, interpenetrating, melting
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: into one another, and forming an organic whole, a living unity or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: personality. It is through a consideration of la duree and what it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: implies that Bergson is led on to the distinction of two selves in each
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of us.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Towards the close of his essay on Time and Free Will, he points out that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there are finally two different selves, a fundamental self and a social
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: self. We reach the former by deep introspection which leads us to grasp
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our inner states as living things, constantly becoming, never amenable
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to measure, which permeate one another and of which the succession in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: la duree has nothing in common with side-by-sideness. But the moments at
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which we thus grasp ourselves are rare; the greater part of our time we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: live outside ourselves, hardly perceiving anything of ourselves but our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the real and largely concealed Ego. Hence our life unfolds in space
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rather than in time. We live for the external world rather than for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ourselves, we speak rather than think, we are "acted" rather than "act"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ourselves. To act freely, however, is to recover possession of one's
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: real self and to get back into la duree reele. [Footnote: Time and Free
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Real Time, then, is a living reality, not discrete, not spatial in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: character--an utter contrast to that fictitious Time with which so many
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thinkers have busied themselves, setting up "as concrete reality the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: distinct moments of a Time which they have reduced to powder, while the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: unity which enables us to call the grains 'powder' they hold to be much
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: more artificial. Others place themselves in the eternal. But as their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: eternity remains, notwithstanding, abstract since it is empty, being
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the eternity of a concept which by hypothesis excludes from itself the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: opposing concept, one does not see how this eternity would permit of an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: indefinite number of moments co-existing in it, an eternity of death,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: since it is nothing else than the movement emptied of the mobility which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: made its life." [Footnote: An Introduction to Metaphysics, pp. 51-54.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

author: Gunn, John Alexander

author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: therefore still moving, eternity in which our own particular duree

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Finally, Bergson reminds us that if our existence were composed of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: separate states, with an impassive Ego to unite them, for us there would
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

author: Gunn, John Alexander

author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: resistant or more substantial than la duree, for our duree is not merely

author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 8 (Fr. p. 8).] Real Time has, then, a very vital meaning for us as

text: identified not only with the reality of change, but with memory and with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: spirit. [Footnote: La Perception du Changement, Lecture 2.] In it he
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: finds the substance of a universe whose reality is change. "God," said
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Plato, "being unable to make the world eternal, gave it Time--a moving
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: image of reality." Bergson himself quotes this remark of Plato, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: seems to have a vision like that of Rosetti's "Blessed Damozel," who        ...... "saw
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time like a pulse shake fierce
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Through all the worlds."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The more we study Time, the more we may grasp this vision ourselves, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: then we shall comprehend that la duree implies invention, the creation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of new forms, the continual elaboration of the absolutely new--in short,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: an evolution which is creative.

text: CHAPTER VII
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: FREEDOM OF THE WILL
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Spirit of man revolts from physical and psychological
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: determinism--Former examined and rejected--The latter more subtle--Vice
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of "associationism"--Psychology without a self. Condemnation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of psychological determinism--Room for freedom--The self in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: action--Astronomical forecasts--Foreseeableness of any human action
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: impossible--Human wills centres of indetermination--Not all our acts
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: free--True freedom, self-determination.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Before passing on to an examination of Bergson's treatment of Evolution,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we must consider his discussion of the problem of Freedom of the Will.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Few problems which have occupied the attention of philosophers have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: been more discussed or have given rise to more controversy than that of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Freedom. This is, of course, natural as the question at issue is one of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: very great importance, not merely as speculative, but also in the realm
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of action. We ask ourselves: "Are we really free?" Can we will either
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of two or more possibilities which are put before us, or, on the other
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: hand, is everything fixed, predestined in such a way that an all-knowing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness could foretell from our past what course our future action
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: would take?
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The study of the physical sciences has led to a general acceptance of a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: principle of causality which is of such a kind that there seems no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: place in the universe for human freedom. Further, there is a type of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: psychology which gives rise to the belief that even mental occurrences
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are as determined as those of the physical world, thus leaving no room
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for autonomy of the Will. But even when presented with the arguments
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which make up the case for physical or psychological determinism,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the spirit of man revolts from it, refuses to accept it as final,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and believes that, in some way or other, the case for Freedom may be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: maintained. It is at this point that Bergson offers us some help in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: solution of the problem, by his Essai sur les donnees immediates de la
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conscience, better described by its English title Time and Free Will.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The arguments for physical determinism are based on the view that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Freedom is incompatible with the fundamental properties of matter, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in particular, with the principle of the conservation of energy. This
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: principle "has been assumed to admit of no exception; there is not an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: atom either in the nervous system or in the whole of the universe whose
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: position is not determined by the sum of the mechanical actions which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the other atoms exert upon it. And the mathematician who knew the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: position of the molecules or atoms of a human organism at a given
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: moment, as well as the position and motion of all the atoms in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: universe, capable of influencing it, could calculate with unfailing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: certainty the past, present, and future actions of the person to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whom this organism belonged, just as one predicts an astronomical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: phenomenon." [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 144 (Fr. p. 110).] Now,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it follows that if we admit the universal applicability of such a theory
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as that of the conservation of energy, we are maintaining that the whole
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: universe is capable of explanation on purely mechanical principles,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inherent in the units of which the universe is composed. Hence, the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: relative position of all units at a given moment, whatever be their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: nature, strictly determines what their position will be in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: succeeding moments, and this mechanistic succession goes on like a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Juggernaut car with crushing unrelentlessness, giving rise to a rigid
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fatalism:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "The moving finger writes; and having writ
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Moves on: nor all thy Piety nor Wit
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Shall lure it back to cancel half a line,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Nor all thy tears wash out a Word of it."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Is there no way out of this cramping circle? We feel vaguely,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intuitively, that there is. Bergson points out to us a way. Even if we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: admit, he says, that the direction and the velocity of every atom of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: matter in the universe (including cerebral matter, i.e., the brain,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which is a material thing) are strictly determined, it would not at
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: all follow from the acceptance of this theorem that our mental life is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: subject to the same necessity. For that to be the case, we should
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have to show absolutely that a strictly determined psychical state
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: corresponds to a definite cerebral state. This, as we have seen, has not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: been proved. It is admitted that to some psychical states of a limited
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: kind certain cerebral states do correspond, but we have no warrant
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whatever for concluding that, because the physiological and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: psychological series exhibit some corresponding terms, the two series
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are absolutely parallel. "To extend this parallelism to the series
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: themselves, in their totality, is to settle a priori the problem of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: freedom." [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 147 (Fr. pp. 112-113).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: How far the two series do run parallel is a question--as we saw in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: chapter on the relation of Soul and Body--for experience, observation,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and experiment to decide. The cases which are parallel are limited, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: involve facts which are independent of the power of the Will.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson then proceeds to an examination of the more subtle and plausible
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: case for psychological determinism. A very large number of our actions
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are due to some motive. There you have it, says the psychological
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: determinist. Your so-called Freedom of the Will is a fiction; in reality
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is merely the strongest motive which prevails and you imagine that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: you "freely willed it." But then we must ask him to define "strongest,"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and here is the fallacy of his argument, for there is no other test
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of which is the strongest motive, than that it has prevailed. Such
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: statements do not help to solve the difficulty at all, for they avoid it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and attempt to conceal it; they are due to a conception of mind which is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: both false and mischievous, viz., Associationism. This view regards
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the self as a collection of psychical states. The existing state of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness is regarded as necessitated by the preceding states. As,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: however, even the associationist is aware that these states differ from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: one another in quality, he cannot attempt to deduce any one of them a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: priori from its predecessors. He therefore endeavours to find a link
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: connecting the two states. That there is such a link as the simple
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "association of ideas" Bergson would not think of denying. What he does
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: deny however, very emphatically, is the associationist statement that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this relation which explains the transition is the cause of it. Even
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: when admitting a certain truth in the associationist view, it is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: difficult to maintain that an act is absolutely determined by its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: motive, and our conscious states by one another. The real mischief of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this view lies, however, in the fact, that it misrepresents the self
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by making it merely a collection of psychical states. John Stuart Mill
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: says, in his Examination of Sir William Hamilton's Philosophy: "I could
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have abstained from murder if my aversion to the crime and my dread of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: its consequences had been weaker than the temptation which impelled me
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to commit it." [Footnote: Quoted by Bergson, Time and Free Will, p. 159
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Fr. p. 122).] Here desire, aversion, fear, and temptation are regarded
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as clear cut phenomena, external to the self which experiences them,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and this leads to a curious balancing of pain and pleasure on purely
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: utilitarian lines, turning the mind into a calculating machine such as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: one might find in a shop or counting-house, and taking no account of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: character of the self that "wills." There is, really, in such a system
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of psychology, no room for self-expression, indeed, no meaning left
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for the term "self." It is only an inaccurate psychology, misled by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: language, which tries to show us the soul determined by sympathy,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: aversion, or hate, as though by so many forces pressing upon it from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: without. These feelings, provided that they go deep enough, make up the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whole soul; in them the character of the individual expresses itself,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: since the whole content of the personality or soul is reflected in each
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of them. Then my character is "me." "To say that the soul is determined
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: under the influence of any one of these feelings, is thus to recognize
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that it is self-determined. The associationist reduces the self to an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: aggregate of conscious states, sensations, feelings, and ideas. But if
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: he sees in these various states no more than is expressed in their name,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: if he retains only their impersonal aspect, he may set them side by side
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for ever without getting anything but a phantom self, the shadow of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Ego, projecting itself into space. If, on the contrary, he takes these
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: psychical states with the particular colouring which they assume in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: case of a definite person, and which comes to each of them by reflection
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from all the others, then there is no need to associate a number
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of conscious states in order to rebuild the person, for the whole
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: personality is in a single one of them, provided that we know how to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: choose it. And the outward manifestation of this inner state will be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: just what is called a free act, since the self alone will have been
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the author of it and since it will express the whole of the self."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: Time and Free Will, pp. 165-166 (Fr. pp. 126-127).] There is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: then room in the universe for a Freedom of the human Will, a definite
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: creative activity, delivering us from the bonds of grim necessity and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fate in which the physical sciences and the associationist psychology
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: alike would bind us. Freedom, then, is a fact, and among the facts which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we observe, asserts Bergson, there is none clearer. [Footnote: Time and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Free Will, p. 221 (Fr. p. 169).] There are, however, one or two things
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which bear vitally upon the question of Freedom and which tend to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: obscure the issue. Of these, the foremost is that once we have acted
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in a particular manner we look back upon our actions and try to explain
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: them with particular reference to their immediate antecedents. Here is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: where the mischief which gives rise to the whole controversy has its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: origin. We make static what is essentially dynamic in character. We call
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a process a thing. There is no such "thing" as Freedom; it is a relation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: between the self and its action. Indeed, it is only characteristic of a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: self IN ACTION, and so is really indefinable. Viewed after the action,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it presents a different aspect; it has then become historical, an event
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in the past, and so we try to explain it as being caused by former
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: events or conditions. This casting of it on to a fixed, rigid plan,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: gives action the appearance of having characteristics related to space
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rather than to time, in the real sense. As already shown in the previous
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: chapter, this is due entirely to our intellectual habit of thinking in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: terms of space, by mathematical time, rather than in terms of living
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: time or la duree.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Another point which causes serious confusion in the controversy is the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: notion that because, when an act has been performed, its antecedents
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: may be reckoned up and their value and relative importance or influence
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: assigned, this is equivalent to saying the actor could not have acted in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: any other way than he did, and, further, that his final act could have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: been foretold from the events which led up to it. It is a fact that in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the realm of physical science we can foretell the future with accuracy.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The astronomer predicts the precise moment and place in which Halley's
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: comet will become visible from our earth. It is also a fact that we say
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of men and women who are our intimate friends: "I knew he (or she) would
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: do such and such a thing" or "It's just like him." We base our judgment
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: on our intimate acquaintance with the character of our friend, but this,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as Bergson points out, "is not so much to predict the future conduct of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our friend as to pass a judgment on his present character--that is to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: say, on his past." [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 184 (Fr. p. 140).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: For, although our feelings and our ideas are constantly changing, yet
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we feel warranted in regarding our friend's character as stable, as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reliable. But, as Mill remarked in his Logic: "There can be no science
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of human nature," because, although we trust in the reliability of our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: friend, although we have faith in his future actions, we do not, and can
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: not, know them. "Tout comprendre c'est tout pardonner." To say that, if
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we knew all the conditions, motives, fears, and temptations which led up
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to the actions of another, we could foretell what he would do, amounts
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to saying that, to do so, we should have actually to become that other
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: person, and so arrive at the point where we act as he did because we are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: him. For Paul to foretell Peter's act, Paul would simply have to become
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Peter. [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 187 (Fr. p. 144).] The very
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reasons which render it possible to foretell an astronomical phenomenon
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are the very ones which prevent us from determining in advance an act
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which springs from our free activity. For the future of the material
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: universe, although contemporaneous with the future of a conscious being,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: has no analogy to it. The astronomer regards time from the point of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: view of mathematics. He is concerned with points placed in a homogeneous
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: time, points which mark the beginning or end of certain intervals. He
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: does not concern himself with the interval in its actual duration. This
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is proved by the fact that, could all velocities in the universe be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: doubled, the astronomical formulae would remain unaffected, for the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: coincidences with which that science deals would still take place, but
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: at intervals half as long. To the astronomer as such, this would make no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: difference, but we, in ourselves, would find that our day did not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: give us the full experience. Situations which arose as a result of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: introduction of "summer time" serve to make this point clear. As then
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we find that time means two different things for the astronomer and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: psychologist, the one being concerned with the points at the extremities
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of intervals, and the other with the enduring reality of the intervals
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: themselves, we can see why astronomical phenomena are capable of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: prediction and see too that, for the same reason, events in the realm
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of human action cannot be so predicted and therefore the future is not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: predetermined but is being made.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Upon exactly parallel lines lie the references to causality in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: controversy. In the physical realm events may recur, but in the mental
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: realm the same thing can never happen again because we are living in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: real, flowing time, or la duree, and our conscious states are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: changing. Admitting that there is that in experience which warrants the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: application of the principle of causality, taking that principle as the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: statement that physical phenomena once perceived can recur, and that a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: given phenomenon, happening only after certain conditions, will recur
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: when those precise conditions are repeated, [Footnote: See the brief
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: paper Notre croyance a la loi de causalite, Revue de metaphysique et
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: de morale, 1900.] still it remains open whether such a regularity of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: succession is ever possible in the human consciousness, and so the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: assertion of the principle of causality proves nothing against Freedom.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We may admit that the principle is based on experience--but what kind of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: experience? Consideration of this question leads us to assert that the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: principle of causality only tends to accentuate the difference between
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: objects in a realm wherein regular succession may be observed and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: predicted and a realm where it may not be observed or predicted, the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: realm of the self. Just because I endure and change I do not necessarily
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: act to-day as I acted yesterday, when under like conditions. We do
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: expect, however, that this will not be the case in the physical realm;
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for example, we expect that a flame applied to dry paper will always
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: set it alight. Indeed, the more we realize the causal relation as one of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: necessary determination, we come to see that things do not exist as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we do ourselves, and distinction between physical and psychical events
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: becomes clear. We perceive that we, in ourselves, are centres of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: indetermination enjoying Freedom, and capable of creative activity.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We must, however, be careful to observe that such Freedom as we have is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: not absolute at all and that it admits of degrees. All our acts are by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: no means free. Indeed, Free Will is exceptional, and many live and die
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: without having known true Freedom. Our everyday life consists in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: performance of actions which are largely habitual or, indeed, automatic,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: being determined not by Free Will, but by custom and convention. Our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Freedom is the exception and not the rule. Through sluggishness or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: indolence, we jog on in the even tenor of a way towards which habit has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: directed us. Even at times when our whole personality ought to vibrate,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: finding itself at the cross-roads, it fails to rise to the occasion.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: But, says Bergson, "it is at the great and solemn crises, decisive of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our reputation with others, and yet more with ourselves, that we choose
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in defiance of what is conventionally called a motive, and this absence
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of any tangible reason, is the more striking the deeper our Freedom
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: goes." [Footnote: Time and Free Will, p. 170 (Fr. p. 130).] At such
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: times the self feels itself free and says so, for it feels itself to be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: creative. "All determinism will thus be refuted by experience, but every
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: attempt to define Freedom will open the way to determinism." [Footnote:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Time and Free Will, p. 330 (Fr. p. 177).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: It has been urged that, although Bergson is a stanch upholder of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Freedom, it is Freedom of such a kind that it must be distinguished from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Free Will, that is, from the liberty of choice which indeterminists have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: asserted and which determinists have denied; and that the Freedom for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which he holds the brief is not the feeling of liberty that we have when
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: confronted with alternative courses of action, or the feeling we have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: when we look back upon a choice made and an action accomplished, that we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: need not have acted as we did, and that we could have acted differently.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Such Freedom it has been further maintained, is of little importance to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: us, for it is merely a free, creative activity which is the essence of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life, which we share with all that lives and so cannot be styled "human"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Freedom. Now, although many of Bergson's expressions, in regard to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: free, creative activity in general, lead to a connexion of this with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the problem of "human" Freedom, such an identification would seem to be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: unfair. This seems specially so when we read over carefully his remarks
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: about the coup d'etat of the fundamental self in times of grave crisis.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We cannot equate this with a purely biological freedom or vitality, or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: spontaneity. But in the light of the criticism which has been made, it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: will be well to consider, in concluding this chapter, the statements
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: made by Bergson in his article on Liberty in the work in connexion with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the Vocabulaire philosophique for the Societe francaise de philosophie:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: Quoted by Le Roy in his Une nouvelle philosophie: Henri
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson, English Translation (Benson), Williams and Norgate, p. 192.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "The word Liberty has for me a sense intermediate between those which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we assign, as a rule, to the two terms 'Liberty' and 'Free Will.' On
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: one hand I believe that 'Liberty' consists in being entirely oneself,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in acting in conformity with oneself; it is then to a certain degree
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the 'moral liberty' of philosophers, the independence of the person
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with regard to everything other than itself. But that is not quite this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Liberty, since the independence I am describing has not always a moral
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: character. Further, it does not consist in depending on oneself as an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: effect depends on the cause which, of necessity, determines it. In this,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: I should come back to the sense of 'Free Will.'" And yet, he continues,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "I do not accept this sense either, since Free Will, in the usual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: meaning of the term, implies the equal possibility of two contraries,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and, on my theory, we cannot formulate or even conceive, in this case,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the thesis of the equal possibility of the two contraries, without
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: falling into grave error about the nature of Time. The object of my
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thesis has been precisely to find a position intermediate between 'moral
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Liberty' and 'Free Will.' Liberty, such as I understand it, is situated
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: between these two terms, but not at equal distances from both; if I were
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: obliged to blend it with one of the two, I should select 'Free-Will.'"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Nor is Liberty to be reduced to spontaneity. "At most, this would be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the case in the animal world where the psychological life is principally
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that of the affections. But in the case of a man, a thinking being,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the free act can be called a synthesis of feelings and ideas, and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: evolution which leads to it, a reasonable evolution." [Footnote: Matter
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and Memory, p. 243 (Fr. p. 205).] "In a word, if it is agreed to call
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: every act free, which springs from the self, and from the self alone,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the act which bears the mark of our personality is truly free, for our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: self alone will lay claim to its paternity." [Footnote: Time and Free
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Will, p. 172 (Fr. p. 132). It is interesting to compare with this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the remark by Nietzsche in Also sprach Zarathustra, Thus Spake
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Zarathustra,--"Let your Ego be in relation to your acts that which the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mother is in relation to the child."] The secret of the solution lies
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: surely here, and in the words given above: "Liberty consists in being
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: entirely oneself." If we act rightly we shall act freely, and yet be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: determined. Yet here there will be no contradiction, for we shall be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: self-determined. It is only the man who is self-determined that can
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in any sense be said to know the meaning of "human" Freedom. "We call
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: free," said Spinoza, "that which exists in virtue of the necessities of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: its own nature, and which is determined by itself alone." Liberty is not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: absolute, for then we ourselves would be at the beck and call of every
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: external excitation, desire, passion, or temptation. Our salvation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consists in self-determination, so we shall avoid licence but preserve
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Freedom. We can only repeat the Socratic maxim--"Know thyself"--and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: resolve to take to heart the appeal of our own Shakespeare:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "To thine own self be true!"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
