text: Work of Darwin and Spencer--Bergson's L'Evolution
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: creatrice--Life--L'elan vital--Evolution not progress in a straight
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: line--Adaptation an insufficient explanation--Falsity of mechanistic
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: view--Finalist conception of reality as fulfilling a plan false--Success
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: along certain lines only--Torpor, Instinct, and Intelligence--Genesis
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of matter--Humanity the crown of evolution--Contingency and Freedom--The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Future is being created.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Since the publication of Darwin's famous work on The Origin of Species
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in 1859, the conception of Evolution has become familiar and has won
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: general acceptance in all thinking minds. Evolution is now a household
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: word, but the actual study of evolutionary process has been the work of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: comparatively few. Science nowadays has become such a highly specialized
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: affair, that few men cover a large enough field of study to enable them
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to deal effectively with this tremendous subject. What is more, those
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: who shouted so loudly about Evolution as explaining all things have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: come to see that, in a sense, Evolution explains nothing by itself. Mere
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: description of facts undoubtedly does serve a very useful purpose and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: may help to demolish some of the stanchly conservative theories still
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: held in some quarters by those who prefer to take Hebrew conceptions as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a basis of their cosmology however irreconcilable with fact these may
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: prove to be. Mere description, however, is not ultimate, some philosophy
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Evolution must be forthcoming. "Nowadays," remarks Hoffding, "every
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosopher has to take up a position with respect to the concept
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Evolution. It has now achieved its place among the categories or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: essential forms of thought by the fact of its providing indications
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whence new problems proceed. We must ask regarding every event, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: every phenomenon, by what stages it has passed into its actual state.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: It is a special form of the general concept of cause. A philosophy
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is essentially characterized by the position which it accords to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this concept and by the way in which it applies it." [Footnote: The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Philosophy of Evolution--lecture IV, of Lectures on Bergson, in Modern
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Philosophers, Translated by Mason (MacMillan), p. 270.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: No one has done more to make familiar to English minds the notion of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Evolution than Herbert Spencer. His Synthetic Philosophy had a grand
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: aim, but it was manifestly unsatisfactory. The high hopes it had raised
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: were followed by mingled disappointment and distrust. The secret of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: unsatisfactoriness of Spencer is to be found in his method, which is an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: elaborate and plausible attempt to explain the evolution of the universe
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by referring the complex to the simple, the more highly organized to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the less organized. His principle of Evolution never freed itself from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: bondage to mechanical conceptions.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson's Creative Evolution, his largest and best known work, appeared
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in 1907. It has been regarded not only as a magnificent book, but as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a date in the history of thought. Two of the leading students of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: evolutionary process in England, Professors Geddes and Thomson, refer to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the book as "one of the most profound and original contributions to the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophical consideration of the theory of Evolution." [Footnote: In
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the Bibliography in their volume Evolution.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: For some time there had been growing a need for an expression of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: evolutionary theory in terms other than those of Spencer, or of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Haeckel--the German monistic philosopher. The advance in the study of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: biology and the rise of Neo-Vitalism, occasioned by an appreciation of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the inadequacy of any explanation of life in terms purely physical and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: chemical, made the demand for a new statement, in greater harmony with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: these views, imperative. To satisfy this demand is the task to which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson has applied himself. He sounds the note of departure from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the older conceptions right at the commencement by his very title,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 'Creative' Evolution. For this, his views on Change, on Time, and on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Freedom, have in some degree prepared us. We have seen set forth
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the fact of Freedom, the recognition of human beings as centres of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: indetermination, not mere units in a machine, "a block universe" where
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: all is "given," but creatures capable of creative activity. Then by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a consideration of Time, as la duree, we found that the history of an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: individual can never repeat itself; "For a conscious being, to exist
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is to change, to change is to mature, to mature is to go on creating
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: oneself endlessly. Should the same be said," Bergson asks, "of existence
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in general?" [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 8 (Fr. p. 8).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: So he proceeds to portray with a wealth of analogy and brilliance of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: style, more akin to the language of a poet than a philosopher, the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: stupendous drama of Evolution, the mystery of being, the wonders of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life. He makes the great fact of life his starting point. Is life
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: susceptible to definition? We feel that, by the very nature of the case,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is not. A definition is an intellectual operation, while life is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: wider, richer, more fundamental than intellect. Indeed Bergson shows us
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that intellect is only one of the manifestations or adaptations of life
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in its progress. To define life, being strictly impossible, Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: attempts to describe it. He would have us picture it as a great current
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: emerging from some central point, radiating in all directions, but
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: diverted into eddies and backwaters. Life is an original impetus, une
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: poussee formidable, not the mere heading affixed to a class of objects
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which live. We must not speak any longer of life in general as an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: abstraction or a category in which we may place all living beings. Life,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or the vital impulse, consists in a demand for creation, we might almost
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: say "a will to create." It appears to be a current passing from one germ
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to another through the medium of a developed organism, "an internal
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: push that has carried life by more and more complex forms, to higher
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and higher destinies." It is a dynamic continuity, a continuity of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: qualitative progress, a duration which leaves its bite on things.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: For these descriptions of life, see Creative Evolution,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: pp. 27-29 and 93-94 (Fr. pp. 28-30 and 95-96).] We shall be absolutely
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: wrong, however, if we attempt to view the evolutionary process as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: progressive in a straight line. The facts contradict such a facile
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and shallow view. Some of the stock phrases of the earlier writers
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: on Evolution were: "adaptation to environment," "selection" and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "variation," and a grave problem was presented by this last. How are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we to account for the variations of living beings, together with the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: persistence of their type? Herein lies the problem of the origin of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: species. Three different solutions have been put forward. There is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the "Neo-Darwinian" view which attributes variation to the differences
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inherent in the germ borne by the individual, and not to the experience
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or behaviour of the individual in the course of his existence. Then
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there is the theory known as "Orthogenesis" which maintains that there
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is a continual changing in a definite direction from generation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to generation. Thirdly, there is the "Neo-Lamarckian" theory which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: attributes the cause of variation to the conscious effort of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: individual, an effort passed on to descendants. [Footnote: Concerning
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Lamarck (1744-1829) Bergson remarks in La Philosophie (1915) that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: without diminishing Darwin's merit Lamarck is to be regarded as the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: founder of evolutionary biology.] Now each one of these theories
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: explains a certain group of facts, of a limited kind, but two
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: difficulties confront them. We find that on quite distinct and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: widely separated lines of Evolution, exactly similar organs have been
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: developed. Bergson points out to us, in this connexion, the Pecten genus
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of molluscs, which have an eye identical in structure with that of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the eye of vertebrates. [Footnote: The common edible scallop (Pecten
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: maximus) has several eyes of brilliant blue and of very complex
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: structure.] It is obvious, however, that the eye of this mollusc and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the eye of the vertebrate must have developed quite independently, ages
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: after each had been separated from the parent stock. Again, we find that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in all organic evolution, infinite complexity of structure accompanies
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the utmost simplicity of function. The variation of an organ so highly
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: complex as the eye must involve the simultaneous occurrence of an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: infinite number of variations all co-ordinated to the simple end of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: vision. Such facts as these are incapable of explanation by reference to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: any or all of the three theories of adaptation and variation mentioned.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Indeed they seem capable of explanation only by reference to a single
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: original impetus retaining its direction in courses far removed from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the common origin. "That adaptation to environment is the necessary
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: condition of Evolution we do not question for a moment. It is quite
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: evident that a species would disappear, should it fail to bend to the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conditions of existence which are imposed on it. But it is one thing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to recognize that outer circumstances are forces Evolution must reckon
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with, another to claim that they are the directing causes of Evolution."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 107 (Fr. p. 111).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "The truth is that adaptation explains the sinuosities of the movement
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Evolution, but not the general directions of the movement, still
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: less the movement itself. The road which leads to the town is obliged to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: follow the ups and downs of the hills; it adapts itself to the accidents
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the ground, but the accidents of the ground are not the cause of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the road nor have they given it its direction." [Footnote: Creative
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Evolution, p. 108 (Fr. p. 112).] The evolution of life cannot be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: explained as merely a series of adaptations to accidental circumstances.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Moreover, the mechanistic view, where all is "given," is quite
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inadequate to explain the facts. The finalist or teleological conception
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is not any more tenable, for Evolution is not simply the realization
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of a plan. "A plan is given in advance. It is represented or at least
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: representable, before its realization. The complete execution of it may
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be put off to a distant future or even indefinitely, but the idea is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: none the less formulable at the present time, in terms actually given.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: If, on the contrary, Evolution is a creation unceasingly renewed, it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: creates as it goes on, not only the forms of life but the ideas that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: enable the intellect to understand it. Its future overflows its present
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and cannot be sketched out therein, in an idea. There is the first error
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of finalism. It involves another yet more serious. If life realizes a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: plan it ought to manifest a greater harmony the further it advances,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: just as the house shows better and better the idea of the architect as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: stone is set upon stone." [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 108 (Fr. p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 112).] Such finalism is really reversed mechanism. If, on the contrary,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the unity of life is to be found solely in the impetus (poussee
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: formidable) that pushes it along the road of Time, the harmony is not in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: front but behind. The unity is derived from a vis a tergo: it is given
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: at the start as an impulsion, not placed at the end as an attraction, as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a kind of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "... far-off divine event
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: To which the whole creation moves."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "In communicating itself the impetus splits up more and more. Life,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in proportion to its progress, is scattered in manifestations
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which undoubtedly owe to their common origin the fact that they are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: complementary to each other in certain aspects, but which are none the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: less mutually incompatible and antagonistic. So that the discord between
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: species will go on increasing." "There are species which are arrested,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there are some that retrogress. Evolution is not only a movement
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: forward; in many cases we observe a marking-time, and still more often
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a deviation or turning back. Thence results an increasing disorder. No
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: doubt there is progress, if progress means a continual advance in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: general direction determined by a first impulsion; but this progress is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: accomplished only on the two or three great lines of Evolution on which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: forms ever more and more complex, ever more and more high, appear;
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: between these lines run a crowd of minor paths in which deviations,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: arrests, and set-backs are multiplied." [Footnote: Creative Evolution,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: pp. 107-110 (Fr. pp. 111-114).] Evolution would be a very simple and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: easy process to understand if it followed one straight path. To describe
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it, Bergson uses, in one place, this metaphor: "We are here dealing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with a shell which has immediately burst into fragments, which, being
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: themselves species of shells, have again burst into fragments, destined
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to burst again, and so on." [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 103 (Fr.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: A study of the facts shows us three very marked tendencies which may
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be denoted by the terms "Torpor," "Instinct," and "Intelligence." These
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are, in a sense "terminal points" in the evolutionary process. Hence
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: arises the distinction of plant and animal, one showing a tendency to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: unconscious torpor, the other manifesting a tendency towards movement
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and consciousness. Then again arises another divergence which gives rise
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to two paths or tendencies, one along the line of the arthropods, at the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: end of which come the ants and the bees with their instincts, and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: other along the line of the vertebrates, at the end of which is man with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: his intelligence. These three, Torpor, Instinct, and Intelligence, must
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: not, however, be looked upon as three successive stages in the linear
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: development of one tendency, but as three diverging directions of a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: common activity, which split up as it went on its way. Instinct and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intelligence are the two important terminal points in Evolution. They
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are not two stages of which one is higher than the other, they are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: at the end of two different roads. The wonders of Instinct are a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: commonplace to students of animal and insect life. [Footnote: See the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: interesting books by the French writer, Henri Fabre.] Men, with their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intellect, make tools, while Instinct is tied to its tool. There is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a wondrous immediacy, however, about Instinct, in the way it achieves
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ends, and its operations are often quite unconsciously performed. The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: insect or animal could not possibly "know" all that was involved in its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: action. Instinct, then, is one form of adaptation, while Intellect is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: quite another. In man--the grown man--Intellect is seen at its best. Yet
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we are not without Instincts; by them we are bound to the race and to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the whole animal creation. But in ants and bees and such like creatures,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Instinct is the sole guide of life, and it is often a highly organized
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life. The following example clearly shows the contrast between Instinct
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and Intelligence. A cat knows how to manage her new-born kittens, how to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: bring them up and teach them; a human mother does not know how to manage
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: her baby unless she is trained either directly or by her own quick
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: observation of other mothers. A cat performs her simple duties by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Instinct, a human mother has to make use of her Intelligence in order to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fulfil her very complex duties. We must observe, however, the relative
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: value of Instinct and Intelligence. Each is a psychical activity, but
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: while Instinct is far more perfect, far more complete in its insight, it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is confined within narrow limits. Intelligence, while far less perfect
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in accomplishing its work, less complete in insight, is not limited
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in such a way. But while Intellect is external, looking on reality as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: different from life, Instinct is an inner sympathy with reality; it is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: deeper than any intellectual bond which binds the conscious creature to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reality, for it is a vital bond.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson now turns to a consideration of Life and Matter in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: evolutionary process, and their precise relation to one another. Life is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: free, spontaneous, incalculable, not out of relation to Matter, but
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: its direction is not entirely determined by Matter nor has its initial
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: impulse Matter as its source. Although Bergson denies that Will and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Consciousness, as we know them, are mere functions of the material
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: organism, yet they do depend upon it as a workman depends upon his tool.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We are fond of insinuating that a bad workman always blames his tools.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: A good workman, however, cannot be expected to do the best work with bad
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: tools. The tool, although he uses it, at the same time limits him. So
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is with the material organism at our disposal, our body, and so,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: too, with spirit and matter in general. Spirit and Matter are not to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be regarded as independent or as ranged against one another from all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: eternity. Matter is a product of Spirit or Consciousness, the underlying
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: psychic force. "For want of a better word," says Bergson, "we have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: called it Consciousness. But we do not mean the narrowed consciousness
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that functions in each of us." [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 250
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Fr. p. 258).] It is rather super-Consciousness than a consciousness
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: like ours. Matter is a flux rather than a thing, but its flow is in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: opposite direction to that of Spirit. The flow of Spirit shows itself
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in the creativeness of the evolutionary process; Matter is the inverse
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement towards stability. Bergson adheres to the view of Spirit as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fundamental, while Matter, he says, is due to a lessening of the tension
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the spiritual force which is the initial elan. Now, of course, Matter
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and Spirit have come to be two opposing forces, for one is determined
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and the other free. Yet Bergson has to make out that there must have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: been some indetermination in Matter, however small, to give Spirit an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: opening to "insinuate itself" into Matter and thus use it for its own
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ends. It always seems, however, as if Spirit were trying to free itself
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from material limitations. It evolved the Intellect to cope with Matter.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: This is why Reason is at home, not in life and freedom, but in solid
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Matter, in mechanical and spatial distinctions. There is thus an eternal
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conflict in progress between Spirit and Matter. The latter is always
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: tending to automatism, to the sacrifice of the Spirit with its creative
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: power. In his little book on The Meaning of the War Bergson claims
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that here we have an instance of Life and Matter in conflict--Germany
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: representing a mechanical and materialistic force. In quite another way
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: he illustrates the same truth, in his book on Laughter, where he shows
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: us that "rigidity, automatism, absent-mindedness, and unsociability, are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: all inextricably entwined, and all serve as ingredients to the making up
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the comic in character," [Footnote: Laughter, p. 147 (Fr. p. 151).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for "the comic is that side of a person which reveals his likeness to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a thing, that aspect of human events which, through its peculiar
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inelasticity, conveys the impression of pure mechanism, of automatism,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of movement without life." [Footnote: Laughter, p. 87 (Fr. p. 89).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Finally, in reviewing the evolutionary process as a whole, Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: asserts that it manifests a radical contingency. The forms of life
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: created, also the proportion of Intuition to Intelligence, in man, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the physique and morality of man, are all of them contingent. Life
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: might have stored up energy in a different way through plants selecting
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: different chemical elements. The whole of organic chemistry would then
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have been different. Then, too, it is probable that Life manifests
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: itself in other planets, in other solar systems also, in forms of which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we have no idea. He points out that between the perfect humanity and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ours one may conceive many possible intermediaries, corresponding to all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the degrees imaginable of Intelligence and Intuition. Another solution
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: might have issued in a humanity either more intelligent or more
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intuitive. Man has warred like the other species, he has warred
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: against the other species. If the evolution of life had been opposed by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: different accidents en route, if the current of life had been divided
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: otherwise, we should have been, in physique and in morality, very
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: different from what we are. [Footnote: Creative Evolution, pp. 280-282
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Fr. p. 288-290).] We cannot regard humanity as prefigured in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: evolutionary process, nor look on man as the ultimate outcome of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: whole of Evolution. The rest of Nature does not exist simply for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the sake of man. Certainly man stands highest, for only in man has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness succeeded, but man has, as it were, lost much in coming
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to this position. The whole process of Evolution "IS AS IF A VAGUE AND
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: FORMLESS BEING, WHOM WE MAY CALL, AS WE WILL, man OR super-man, HAD
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: SOUGHT TO REALIZE HIMSELF AND HAD SUCCEEDED ONLY BY ABANDONING A PART OF
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: HIMSELF ON THE WAY." [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 281 (Fr. p. 289).
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: (Italics are Bergson's.)]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In the lectures on The Nature of the Soul, Bergson referred to the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "Pathway of the evolutionary process" as being a "Way to Personality."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: For on the line which leads to man liberation has been accomplished and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thus personalities have been able to constitute themselves. If we could
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: view this line of evolution it would appear to resemble a telegraph
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: wire on which has travelled a dispatch sent off as long ago as the first
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: beginnings of life, a message which was then confused, of which a part
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: has been lost on the way, but which has at last found in the human race
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the appropriate instrument.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Humanity is one; we are members one of another. Bergson insists on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this solidarity of man, and, indeed, of all living creatures. "As the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: smallest grain of dust is bound up with our entire solar system, drawn
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: along with it in that undivided movement of descent which is materiality
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: itself, so all organized beings, from the humblest to the highest, from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the first origins of life to the time in which we are, and in all places
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as in all times, do but evidence a single impulsion, the inverse of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the movement of matter, and in itself indivisible. All the living hold
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: together and all yield to the same tremendous push. The animal takes its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: stand on the plant, man bestrides animality, and the whole of humanity,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in space and in time, is one immense army galloping beside and before
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and behind each of us, in an overwhelming charge, able to beat down
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: every resistance and clear the most formidable obstacles, perhaps even
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: death." [Footnote: Creative Evolution, pp. 285-286 (Fr. pp. 293-294).]
