author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: CHAPTER IX
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: THE GOSPEL OF INTUITION
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intelligence and Intuition not opposed--Intellectual sympathy--Synthesis
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and analysis. "Understanding as one loves"--Concepts--Intellect not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: final--Man's spirit and intuitions--Joy, creative power and art--Value
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Intuitive Philosophy.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We now approach the grand climax of Bergson's philosophy, his doctrine
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Intuition, which he preaches with all the vigour of an evangelist.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Our study of his treatment of Change, of Perception, of la duree, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Instinct, has prepared us for an investigation of what he means by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition, for in dealing with these subjects he has been laying the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: foundations of his doctrine of Intuition. He pointed out to us that Life
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is Change, but that our intellect does not really grasp the reality of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Change, for it is adapted to solids and to concepts, it resembles the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: cinematograph film. Then he has tried to show us that in Perception
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there is really much more than we think, for our intellect carves out
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: what is of practical interest, while the penumbra or vague fringes
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of perceptions which have no bearing on action are neglected. By his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: advocacy of a real psychological Time, in opposition to the physical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: abstraction which bears the name, he again brought out the inadequacy of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intellect to grasp Life in its flow and has put before us the soul's own
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: appreciation of Time, which is a valuation rather than a magnitude,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: an intuition of our consciousness. Then, in examining the Evolution
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Instinct and Intelligence, we found that Instinct, however blind
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intellectually, contained a wonderful and unique element of immediacy or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: direct insight. These are just preparatory indications of the direction
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Bergson's thought all the time.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: It is admittedly difficult to determine with very great definiteness
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: what Bergson's view of Intuition really is, for he has made many
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: statements regarding it which appear at first sight irreconcilable and,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in his earlier writings, has not been sufficiently careful when speaking
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the distinction between Intelligence and Intuition. Some of his early
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: statements are reactionary and crude and give the impression of a purely
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: anti-intellectualist position involving the condemnation of Intellect
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and all its work. [Footnote: E.g., the statement "To philosophize is to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: invert the habitual direction of the work of thought"--Introduction to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Metaphysics p. 59.] In his later work, however, Bergson has made it more
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: clear that he does not mean to throw Intellect overboard; it has its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: place, but is not final, nor is it the supreme human faculty which most
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophers have thought it to be. It must be lamented, however, that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson's language was ever so ill defined as to encourage the many
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: varied and conflicting views which are held regarding his doctrine of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition. Around this the greatest controversy has raged. Little is to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be gained by heeding the shouts of either those who acclaim Bergson as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a revolutionary against all use of the Intellect, or of those who regard
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: him as no purely anti-intellectualist at all. We must turn to Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: himself and study carefully what he has said and written, reserving our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: judgment until we have examined his own statements.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: What is this "Intuition"? In what is now a locus classicus [Footnote:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Introduction to Metaphysics, p. 7.] he says, "By Intuition is meant
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the kind of INTELLECTUAL SYMPATHY by which one places oneself within an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: object in order to coincide with what is unique in it and consequently
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: inexpressible. Analysis is the operation which reduces the object to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: elements already known, that is, to elements common to it and other
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: objects. To analyse, therefore, is to express a thing as a function
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of something other than itself. All analysis is thus a translation, a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: development into symbols, a representation taken from successive points
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of view from which we note as many resemblances as possible between the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: new object which we are studying and others which we believe we know
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: already. In its eternally unsatisfied desire to embrace the object
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: around which it is compelled to turn, analysis multiplies without
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: end the number of its points of view in order to complete its always
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: incomplete representation, and ceaselessly varies its symbols that it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: may perfect the always imperfect translation. It goes on therefore to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: infinity. But Intuition, if Intuition be possible, is a simple act. It
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is an act directly opposed to analysis, for it is a viewing in totality,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as an absolute; it is a synthesis, not an analysis, not an intellectual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: act, for it is an immediate, emotional synthesis."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Two illustrations, taken from the same essay, may serve to make this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: point clearer. A visitor in Paris, of an artistic temperament, makes
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: some sketches of the city, writing underneath them, by way of memento,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the word "Paris." As he has actually seen Paris he is able, with the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: help of the original Intuition he has had of that unique whole which is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Paris itself, to place his sketches therein, and synthesize them. But
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there is no way of performing the inverse operation. It is impossible,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: even with thousands of sketches, to achieve the Intuition, to give
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: oneself the impression of what Paris is like, if one has never been
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there. Or again, as a second illustration, "Consider a character whose
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: adventures are related to me in a novel. The author may multiply the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: traits of his hero's character, may make him speak and act as much as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: he pleases, but all this can never be equivalent to the simple and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: indivisible feeling which I should experience if I were able, for an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: instant, to identify myself with the person of the hero himself. Out of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that indivisible feeling, as from a spring, all the words, gestures, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: actions of the man would appear to me to flow naturally. They would no
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: longer be accidents which, added to the idea I had already formed of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: character, continually enriched that idea without ever completing it.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The character would be given to me all at once, in its entirety, and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thousand incidents which manifest it, instead of adding themselves to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the idea and so enriching it, would seem to me, on the contrary,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to detach themselves from it, without, however, exhausting it or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: impoverishing its essence. All the things I am told about the man
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: provide me with so many points of view from which I can observe him. All
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the traits which describe him and which can make him known to me, only
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by so many comparisons with persons or things I know already, are signs
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by which he is expressed more or less symbolically. Symbols and points
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of view, therefore, place me outside him; they give me only what he has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in common with others, and not what belongs to him, and to him alone.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: But that which is properly 'himself,' that which constitutes his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: essence, cannot be perceived from without, being internal by definition,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: nor be expressed by symbols, being incommensurable with everything
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: else. Description, history, and analysis leave me here in the relative.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Coincidence with the person himself would alone give me the absolute."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: An Introduction to Metaphysics, p. 3.] This, as Gaston Rageot
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: puts it, is "to understand in the fashion in which one loves." This
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: statement is of suggestive interest in considering the practical problem
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of how we may be said to "know" other people, and has vital bearing on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the revelation of one personality to another, urging, as it does, the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: value and necessity of some degree of sympathy and indeed of love, for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the full understanding and knowledge of any personality.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In another place Bergson says: "When a poet reads me his verses, I can
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: interest myself enough in him to enter into his thought, put myself
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: into his feelings, live over again the simple state he has broken into
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: phrases and words. I sympathize then with his inspiration, I follow it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with a continuous movement which is, like the inspiration itself, an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: undivided act." If this sympathy could extend its object and so reflect
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: upon itself, it would give us the key to vital operations in the same
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: way as Intelligence, developed and corrected, introduces us into Matter.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intelligence, by the intermediary of science, which is its work, tells
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: more and more completely the secret of physical operations; of Life it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: gives and pretends only to give an expression in terms of inertia. We
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: should be led into the very interior of Life by Intuition, that is,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by Instinct become disinterested, conscious of itself, capable of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reflecting on its object and enlarging it indefinitely.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In proclaiming the gospel of Intuition, Bergson's main point is to show
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that man is capable of an experience and a knowledge deeper than that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which the Intellect can possibly give. "At intervals a soul arises which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: seems to triumph... by dint of simplicity--the soul of an artist or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a poet, which, remaining near its source, reconciles, in a harmony
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: appreciable by the heart, terms irreconcilable by the intelligence"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: From the address on Ravaisson, delivered before the Academie
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: des Sciences morales et politiques 1904.] His point of view is here akin
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to that of an earlier French thinker, Pascal, who said: "The heart hath
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: reasons that the reason cannot know." The Intellect is, by its nature,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the fabricator of concepts, and concepts are, in Bergson's view,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mischievous. They are static, they leave out the flux of things, they
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: omit too much of experience, they are framed at an expensive cost, the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: expense of vital contact with Life itself. Of course he admits a certain
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: value in concepts, but he refuses to admit that they help us at all to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: grasp reality in its flux. "Metaphysics must transcend concepts in order
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to reach Intuition. Certainly concepts are necessary to it, for all the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: other sciences work, as a rule, with concepts, and Metaphysics cannot
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: dispense with the other sciences. But it is only truly itself when it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: goes beyond the concept, or at least when it frees itself from rigid and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ready-made concepts, in order to create a kind very different from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: those which we habitually use; I mean supple, mobile, and almost fluid
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: representations, always ready to mould themselves on the fleeting forms
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Intuition." [Footnote: An Introduction to Metaphysics, p. 18.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The true instrument of Metaphysics is intuition. We can only grasp
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ourselves, Bergson points out, by a metaphysical Intuition, for the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: soul eludes thought; we cannot place it among concepts or in a category.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition, however, reveals to us Real Time (la duree) and our real
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: selves, changing and living as free personalities in a Time which, as it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: advances, creates.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition is in no way mysterious, Bergson claims. Every one of us
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: has had opportunities to exercise it in some degree, and anyone, for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: example, who has been engaged in literary work, knows perfectly well
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that after long study has been given to the subject, when all documents
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have been collected and necessary drafts worked out, one thing more is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: needful--an effort, a travail of soul, a setting of oneself in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: heart of the subject; in short, the getting of inspiration. Metaphysical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition seems to be of this nature, and its relation to the empirical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: data contributed by the Intellect is parallel to the relation between
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the literary man's inspiration and his collected material. Of course "it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is impossible to have an Intuition of reality, that is, an intellectual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sympathy, with its innermost nature, unless its confidence has been won
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by a long comradeship with its external manifestation." In his study of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Lucretius [Footnote: Extraits de Lucrece avec etude sur la poesie,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: la philosophie, la physique le texte et la langue de Lucrece (1884).
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Preface, p. xx.] he remarks that the chief value of the Latin
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: poet-philosopher lay in his power of vision, in his insight into the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: beauty of nature, in his synthetic view, while at the same time he was
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: able to exercise his keenly analytic intellect in discovering all he
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: could about the facts of nature in their scientific aspect. At the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: same time, metaphysical Intuition, although only to be obtained through
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: acquaintance with empirical data, is quite other than the mere summary
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of such knowledge. [Footnote: See protest: L'Intuition philosophique in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Revue de metaphysique et de morale, 1911, p. 821.] It is distinct from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: these data, as the motor impulse is distinct from the path traversed
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by the moving body, as the tension of the spring is distinct from the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: visible movements of the pendulum. In this sense Metaphysics has nothing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in common with a generalization of facts. It might, however, be defined
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as "integral experience." Nevertheless Intuition, once attained, must
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: find a mode of expression in well-defined concepts, for in itself it is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: incommunicable. Dialectic is necessary to put Intuition to the proof,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: necessary also in order that Intuition should break itself up into
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: concepts and so be propagated to others. But when we use language and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: concepts to communicate it, we tend to make these in themselves mean
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: something, whereas they are but counters or symbols used to express what
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is their inspiration--Intuition. Hence we often forget the metaphysical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuitions from which science itself has sprung. What is relative in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: science is the symbolic knowledge, reached by pre-existing concepts
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which proceed from the fixed to the moving. A truly intuitive philosophy
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: would bring science and metaphysics together. Modern science dates from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the day when mobility was set up as an independent reality and studied
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as such by Galileo. But men of science have mainly fixed their attention
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: on the concepts, the residual products of Intuition, the symbols which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have lent a symbolic character to every kind of science. Metaphysicians,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: too, have done the same thing. Hence it was easy for Kant to show that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our science is wholly relative and our metaphysics entirely artificial.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: For Kant, science was a universal mathematic and metaphysics a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: practically unaltered Platonism. The synthetic Intuition was hidden
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by the analysis to which it had given rise. For Kant, Intuition was
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: infra-intellectual, but for Bergson it is supra-intellectual. Kant's
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: great error was in concluding that it is necessary for us, in order
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to attain Intuition, to leave the domain of the senses and of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: consciousness. This was because of his views of Time and Change. If Time
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and Change really were what he took them to be, then Metaphysics and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition alike are impossible. For Bergson, however, Time and Change
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: lead up to Intuition; indeed it is by Intuition that we come to see all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: things, as he expresses it, sub specie durationis. This is the primary
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: vision which an intuitive philosophy supplies. Such a philosophy will
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: not be merely a unification of the sciences.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In an article contributed to the Revue de metaphysique et de morale
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in January of 1908, under the title L'Evolution de l'intelligence
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: geometrique, we find Bergson remarking: "Nowhere have I claimed that we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: should replace intelligence by something else, or prefer instinct to it.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: I have tried to show merely that when we leave the region of physical
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and mathematical objects for the realm of life and consciousness, we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have to depend on a certain sense of living, which has its origin in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the same vital impulse that is the basis of instinct, although instinct,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: strictly speaking, is something quite different."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intellect and Intuition, Bergson says very emphatically, at the close
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of his Huxley Lecture on Life and Consciousness, are not opposed to one
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: another. "How could there be a disharmony between our Intuitions and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our Science, how, especially, could our Science make us renounce our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition, if these Intuitions are something like Instinct--an Instinct
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conscious, refined, spiritualized--and if Instinct is still nearer Life
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: than Intellect and Science? Intuition and Intellect do not oppose each
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: other, save where Intuition refuses to become more precise by coming
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: into touch with facts, scientifically studied, and where Intellect,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: instead of confining itself to Science proper (that is, to what can
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be inferred from facts, or proved by reasoning), combines with this
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: an unconscious and inconsistent metaphysic which in vain lays claim to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: scientific pretensions. The future seems to belong to a philosophy which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: will take into account the whole of what is given." [Footnote: Life and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Consciousness, as reported in The Hibbert Journal, Vol. X, Oct., 1911,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: pp. 24-44.] Intuition, to be fruitful, must interact with Intellect.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: It has the direct insight of Instinct, but its range is widened in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: proportion as it blends with Intellect. To imagine that the acceptance
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the gospel of Intuition means the setting aside of all valuation in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: regard to the Intellect and its work would be preposterous. Bergson,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: however unguarded his language at times has been, does not mean this.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: He does not mean that we must return to the standpoint of the animal
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or that we must assume that the animal view, which is instinctive, is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: higher than the view which, through Intellect, gives it a meaning and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: value to the percipient. That would involve the rejection of all that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our culture has accumulated, all our social heritage from the past, the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: overthrow of our civilization, the undoing of all that has developed
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in our world, since man's Intelligence came into it. We cannot obtain
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition without intellectual labour, for it must have an intellectual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or scientific basis. Yet, however valuable Intellect is, it is not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: final. "It is reality itself, in the profoundest meaning of the word,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that we reach by the combined and progressive development of science
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and philosophy." [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 210 (Fr. p. 217).] We
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: need, therefore, if we are to get into touch with the deeper aspects
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of reality, something more than bare science. We cannot live on its dry
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: bread alone; we need philosophy--an intuitional philosophy.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In his brilliant paper L'Intuition philosophique Bergson shows us, by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a splendid study of Berkeley and Spinoza, that the great Intuition
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: underlying the thought of a philosopher is of more worth to the world
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: than the logic and dialectic through the aid of which it is made
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: manifest, and elaborated. [Footnote: He makes this clear in a letter to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Dr. Mitchell in the latter's Studies in Bergson's Philosophy, p. 31.]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Then in the Lectures La Perception du Changement and in his little work
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: on Laughter he sets forth the meaning of Intuition in relation to Art.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: From time to time Nature raises up souls more or less detached from
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: practical life, seers of visions and dreamers of dreams, men of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition, with powers of great poetry, great music, or great painting.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The clearest evidence of Intuition comes to us from the works of these
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: great artists. What is it that we call the "genius" of great painters,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: great musicians, and great poets? It is simply the power they have of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: seeing more than we see and of enabling us, by their expressions, to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: penetrate further into reality ourselves. What makes the picture is the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: artist's vision, his entry into the subject by sympathy or Intuition,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and however imperfectly he expresses this, yet he reveals to us more
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: than we could otherwise have perceived.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The original form of consciousness, Bergson asserts, was nearer to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Intuition than to Intelligence. But man has found Intellect the more
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: valuable faculty for practical use and so has used it for the solution
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of questions it was never intended to solve, by reason of its nature
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and origin. Yet "Intuition is there, but vague and, above all,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: discontinuous. It is a lamp almost extinguished which only glimmers now
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and then for a few moments at most. But it glimmers whenever a vital
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: interest is at stake. On our personality, on our liberty, on the place
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we occupy in the whole of Nature, on our origin, and perhaps also on our
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: destiny, it throws a light, feeble and vacillating, but which, none the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: less, pierces the darkness of the night in which the Intellect leaves
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: us." [Footnote: Creative Evolution, p. 282 (Fr. p. 290).]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Science promises us well-being, or, at the most, pleasure, but
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophy, through the Intuition to which it leads us, is capable
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of bestowing upon us Joy. The future belongs to such an intuitive
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophy, Bergson holds, for he considers that the whole progress of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Evolution is towards the creation of a type of being whose Intuition
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: will be equal to his Intelligence. Finally, by Intuition we shall find
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ourselves in--to invent a word--"intunation" with the elan vital,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with the Evolution of the whole universe, and this absolute feeling of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "at-one-ment" with the universe will result in that emotional synthesis
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which is deep Joy, which Wordsworth describes as:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "that blessed mood
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In which the burthen of the mystery,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In which the heavy and the weary weight
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Of all this unintelligible world,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Is lightened:--that serene and blessed mood,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In which the affections gently lead us on,--
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Until, the breath of this corporeal frame
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: And even the motion of our human blood
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Almost suspended, we are laid asleep
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In body, and become a living soul:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: While with an eye made quiet by the power
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Of harmony and the deep power of joy
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We see into the life of things."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: CHAPTER X
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ETHICAL AND POLITICAL IMPLICATIONS
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Anti-intellectualism and the State--Syndicalism--Class war,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "direct action." Sorel advocates General Strike--Bergson cited in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: support--Unfair use of Bergson's view of reality--His ethic--Value
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Will and Creativeness; not a supporter of impulse. Development of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: personality. Intuitive mind of woman. Change and the moral life.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson has not written explicitly upon Ethics. In some quarters,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: however, so much has been made of Bergson as a supporter of certain
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ethical tendencies and certain social movements, that we must examine
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this question of ethical and political implications and try to ascertain
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: how far this use of Bergson is justified.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Both ethical and political thought to-day are deriving fresh stimulation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from the revision of many formulae, the modification of many conceptions
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which the War has inevitably caused. At the same time the keen interest
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: taken in studies like social psychology and political philosophy
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: combines with a growing interest in movements such as Guild Socialism
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and Syndicalism. The current which in philosophy sets against
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intellectualism, in the political realm sets against the State. This
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: political anti-intellectualism shows a definite tendency to belittle
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the State in comparison with economic or social groups. "If social
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: psychology tends to base the State as it is, on other than intellectual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: grounds, Syndicalism is prone to expect that non-intellectual forces
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: will suffice to achieve the State as it should be." [Footnote: Ernest
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Barker in his Political Thought in England from Herbert Spencer to the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Present Day, p. 248.] Other tendencies of the same type are noticeable.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: For example, Mr. Bertrand Russell's work on The Principles of Social
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Reconstruction is based on the view that impulse is a larger factor in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: our social life than conscious purpose.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The Syndicalists have been citing the philosophy of Bergson in support
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of their views, and it is most interesting to see how skilfully at times
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: sayings of Bergson are quoted by them as authoritative, as justification
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for their actions, in a spirit akin to that of the devout man who quotes
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: scripture texts as a guide to conduct.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In this country, Syndicalism has not been popular, and when it did show
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: its head the government promptly prosecuted the editor and printers
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of its organ, The Syndicalist, and suppressed the paper owing to its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: aggressive anti-militarism. [Footnote: Imprisonment of Mr. Tom Mann]
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: English Syndicalism has few supporters and it is a rather diluted form
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of French Syndicalism. To understand the movement, we must turn to its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: history in France or in America. Its history in Russia will be an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: object of research in the future, when more material and more news are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: available from that "distressful country." In France local unions or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: syndicats were legalized as early as 1884 but 1895 is the important
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: landmark, being the date of the foundation with which Syndicalism is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: associated to-day, the Confederation Generale du Travail, popularly
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: known as the "C.G.T.," the central trade-union organization in France.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In the main, Syndicalism is an urban product, and has not many adherents
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: among the agricultural population. In America a "Federation of Labour"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: was formed in 1886, but the Syndicalist organization there is the body
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: known as "The Industrial Workers of the World." In its declaration
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of policy, it looks forward to a union which is to embrace the whole
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: working class and to adopt towards the capitalist class an unending
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: warfare, until the latter is expropriated. "The working class and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: employing class," says the declaration, "have nothing in common. Between
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: these two classes a struggle must go on until all the toilers come
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: together on the industrial field and take and hold that which they
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: produce by their labour." Among the leaders of Syndicalist thought on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the Continent may be mentioned the names of three prominent Frenchmen,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Berth, Lagardelle, and Sorel, together with that of the young Italian
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: professor Labriola, who is leading the increasingly active party in his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: own country.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In France, Italy, and America alike, Syndicalism stands for the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: class-war. Its central feature is the idea of a General Strike. It
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: manifests a hatred of the State, which makes it bitterly opposed to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: State Socialism, which it regards as centralized and tyrannical, or to a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Labour-party of any kind in Parliament. [Footnote: Attempts at carrying
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: out a General Strike, in France, Sweden, Italy, and Spain have failed.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The greatest Strikes have been: Railwaymen in Italy, in 1907; Postal
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Workers in France, in 1909. Miners in New South Wales, in 1909, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in Sweden, 1909; Miners and Railwaymen in England; Textile Workers in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Massachusetts, 1912; Railwaymen in England, 1919, in France, 1920.] It
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: regards the State as fixed, rigid, and intellectual, and adopts all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the Bergsonian anathemas it can find which condemn intellectual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: constructions, concepts, and thought in general. Its war-cry is not only
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "Down with Capitalism" but also, in a great number of cases, "Down
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with Intellectualism"! Instinct and impulse alone are to be guides.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Syndicalism, unlike Socialism, has no programme--it does not believe in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a prearranged plan. Reality, it says, quoting Bersgon, has no plan. It
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: says, "Let us act, act instinctively and impulsively against what we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: feel to be wrong, and the future will grow out of our acting." We find
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Georges Sorel, the philosopher of Syndicalism, talking about what he
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: terms the INTUITION of Socialism, and he talks emphatically about the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: tremendous moral value of strikes, apart from any material gain achieved
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by them. He believes religiously in a General Strike as the great ideal,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: but considers it a myth capable of rousing enthusiasm in the workers,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: an ideal to which they must strive, a myth as inspiring as the belief
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the early Christians in the Second Coming of Christ, which, although
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: quite a false belief, contributed largely to the success of the early
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Church. "Strikes," says Sorel, "have engendered in the proletariat the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: most noble, the most profound, the most moving sentiments they possess.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The General Strike groups these in a composite picture, and by bringing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: together, gives to each its maximum intensity; appealing to the most
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: acute memories of particular conflicts, it colours with an intense life
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: all the details of the composition presented to the mind. We obtain thus
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: an intuition of Socialism which language cannot clearly express and we
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: obtain it in a symbol instantly perceived, such as is maintained in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the Bergsonian philosophy." [Footnote: Quoted by C. Bougle, in an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: interesting article Syndicalistes et Bergsoniens, Revue du mois, April
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 10, 1909. And by Rev. Rhondda Williams in Syndicalism in France and its
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Relation to the Philosophy of Bergson, Hibbert Journal, 1914. Also by
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: J. W. Scott in his book Syndicalism and Philosophical Realism, 1919, pp.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 39-40, and by Harley in Syndicalism.] In England, although the idea
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the General Strike has not been so prominent, yet in recent years
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Strikes have assumed an aspect different from those of former years.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Workers who had "struck" before for definite objects, for wages or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: hours, or reformed workshop conditions, now seem to be seeking after
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: something vaster--a fundamental alteration in industrial conditions or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the total abolition of the present system. The spirit of unrest is on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the increase; no doubt War conditions have, in many cases, intensified
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it, but there is in the whole industrial world an instinctive impulse
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: showing itself, which is issuing in Syndicalist and Bolshevist
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: "Bolshevik"--simply the Russian word for majority party as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: distinct from Mensheviks or minority.] activities of various kinds.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Syndicalism is undoubtedly revolutionary. There are Les Syndicats
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rouges and Les Syndicats jaunes, of which the "Reds" are by far the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: most revolutionary. [Footnote: See article Des Ouvriers syndiques et le
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Syndicalisme jaune, Revue de metaphysique et morale, 1912] The C.G.T.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and the Industrial Workers of the World are out for what they call
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "direct action." Their anarchy is really an organization directed
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: against organization, at least against that organization we know as the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: modern State. They have no hope of salvation for themselves coming about
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: through the State in any way. It has become somewhat natural for us
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to think of the social reformer as a Member of Parliament and of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: revolutionary socialist as a "strike-agitator." The cries of "Don't
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: vote!" "Don't enlist!" are heard, and care is taken to keep the workman
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: from ceasing to quarrel with his employer. Any discussion of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rights or wrongs of any Strike is condemned at once. [Footnote: Ramsay
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: MacDonald was condemned by the Syndicalists for claiming that a strike
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: MIGHT be wrong.] All Strikes are regarded as right and as an approach
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to the ideal of the General Strike. Sorel cites Bergson as calling us
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to turn from traditional thought, to seek reality in the dynamic, rather
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: than the static. He claims that the Professor of Philosophy at the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: College de France really co-operates with the C.G.T. An unexpected
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: harmony arises "between the flute of personal meditation, and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: trumpet of social revolution, and the workman is inspired by being made
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to feel that the elan ouvrier est frere de l'elan vital." [Footnote:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Quoted by C. Bougie in the article previously mentioned.] As Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: speaks of all movement as unique and indivisible, so the triumphant
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: movement of the General Strike is to be regarded as a whole, no analysis
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is to be made of its parts. As the portals of the future stand wide
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: open, as the future is being made, so Bergson tells us, that is deemed
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: an excuse by the Syndicalists for having no prearranged plan of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conduct of the General Strike, and no conception of what is to be done
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: afterwards. It is unforeseen and unforeseeable. All industries, however,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are to be in the hands of those who work them, the present industrial
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: system is to be swept away. The new order which is to follow will have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: entirely new moral codes. Sorel justifies violence to be used against
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the existing order, but says he wishes to avoid unnecessary blood-shed
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or brutality. [Footnote: Reflections on Violence. It is interesting to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: note that Bergson refers briefly to Sorel as an original thinker whom it
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is impossible to place in any category or class, in La Philosophie, p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 13.] He remarks however, in this connexion, that ancient society, with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: all its brutality, compares favourably with modern society which has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: replaced ferocity by cunning. The ancient peoples had less hypocrisy
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: than we have; this, in his opinion, justifies violence in the overthrow
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the modern system and the creation of a nobler ethic than that on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which the modern State is based. For this reason, he disagrees with most
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of his Syndicalist colleagues, and condemns sabotage and also the ca
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: canny policy, both of which are a kind of revenge upon the employer,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: based on the principle of "bad work for bad pay." He would have the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: workers produce well now, and urges that moral progress is to be aimed
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: at no less than material progress.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: It certainly seems, however, that the Syndicalists are making an unfair
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: use of Bergson. They have got hold of three or four points rather out of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: relation to their context, and are making the most of them. These points
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are, chiefly, his remarks against the Intellect, his appreciation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Instinct and Intuition, his insistence on Freedom and on the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Indeterminateness of the Future. In the hands of the Syndicalists these
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: become in effect: "Never mind what you think, rouse up your feeling
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: intensely; act as you feel and then see what you think." Briefly
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this amounts to saying: "Act on impulse, behave instinctively and not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rationally." In too many cases, as we know, this is equivalent to a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: merely selfish "Down tools if you feel like it." Now so far from Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: really giving any countenance to capricious behaviour, or mere impulse,

text: 515, 1912.] Prior to the War, however, we know that Bergson was taking

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: of "Duty" and the significance of "Personality." Although his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: which have an important bearing on personal and social life seem to be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: contained in what he has already written.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In its application to social life, Bergson's philosophy would involve
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the laying of greater stress upon the need for all members of society
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: having larger opportunities of being more fully themselves, of being
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: self-creative and having fuller powers of self-expression as free
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: creative agents. It would lay emphasis upon the value of the personality
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the worker and would combat the systematic converting of him into
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a mere "hand." Thus would be set in clearer light the claims of human
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: personality to create and to enjoy a good life in the widest sense, to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: enter into fuller sympathy and fellowship with other personalities, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: so develop a fuller and richer form of existence than is possible under
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: present social and industrial conditions. It would mean a transvaluation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of all social values, an esteeming of personality before property, a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: recognition of material goods as means to a good life, when employed in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the social service of the spirit of man. It would involve a denunciation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the enslavement of man's spirit to the production of material wealth.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Each man would be a member of a community of personalities, each of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: unique value, treating each other, not as means to their own particular
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: selfish ends, but as ends in themselves. At the same time it would
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: involve the putting of the personality of the citizen in the foremost
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: place in our social and political life, instead of a development of a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: purely class consciousness with its mischievous distinctions.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Articles have been written dealing with Bergson's message to Feminism.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: This point is not without its importance in our modern life. It must
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be admitted that the present system of civilization with its scientific
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: campaign of conquest of the material environment has been the work of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: man's intellect. In the ruder stages of existence women's subordination
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to men may have been necessary and justifiable. But in the development
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of society it has become increasingly less necessary, and humanity
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is now at a stage where the contributions of women to society are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: absolutely vital to its welfare and progress. Woman is proverbially and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rightly regarded as more intuitive than man. This need not be taken to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mean that, given the opportunity of intellectual development (until now
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: practically denied to her), woman would not show as great ability in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: this direction as man. But it is an undeniable fact that woman has kept
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: more closely to the forces of the great life-principle, both by the fact
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that in her rests the creative power for the continuation of the human
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: family and also by the fact that the development of the personalities of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: children has been her function. The subjection in which women have been
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: largely kept until now has not only hindered them from taking part in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the work of society as a whole and from expressing their point of view,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: but has meant that many of them have little or no knowledge of their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: capacities and abilities in wider directions. However, with their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: increasing realization of their own powers, with the granting of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: increased opportunities to them, and an adequate recognition of their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: personality side by side with that of men, achievements of supreme value
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for humanity as a whole may be expected from them. In certain spheres
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: they may be found much better adapted than are men to achieve a vision
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which will raise human life to a higher plane and give it greater worth.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: More especially in the realms of ethical development, of social science,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: problems of sex, of war and peace, of child welfare, health, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: education, of religion and philosophy we may hope to have valuable
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: contributions from the more intuitive mind of woman. "It is not in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fighting male of the race: it is in Woman that we have the future centre
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Power in civilization." [Footnote: Benjamin Kidd in The Science
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of Power, p. 195. This is more fully shown in his chapters, Woman the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: Woman, pp. 192-257.] The wandering Dante required for his guidance
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: not only the intellectual faculties of a Vergil but in addition the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
