text: intuitive woman-soul of a Beatrice to lead him upward and on.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In La Conscience et la Vie [Footnote: L'Energie spirituelle, p.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: 27 (Mind-Energy).] Bergson indicates slightly his views on SOCIAL
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: evolution--c'est a la vie sociale que l'evolution aboutit, comme si le
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: besoin s'en etait fait sentir des le debut, ou plutot comme si quelque
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: aspiration originelle et essentielle de la vie ne pouvait trouver que
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: dans la societe sa pleine satisfaction. He seems inclined to turn his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: attention to the unity of life, not simply as due to an identity of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: original impulse but to a common aspiration. There is involved a process
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of subordination and initiative on the part of the individual. The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: existence of society necessitates a certain subordination, while
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: its progress depends on the free initiative of the individual. It is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: extremely dangerous for any society, whether it be an International
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: League, a State, either Communistic or Capitalistic, a Trade Union, or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a Church, to suppress individual liberty in the interests of greater
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: social efficiency or of increased production or rigid uniformity of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: doctrine. With the sacrifice of individual initiative will go the loss
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of all "soul," and the result will be degeneration to a mechanical type
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of existence, a merely stagnant institution expressing nothing of man's
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: spirit. This personal power of initiative Bergson appeals to each one
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to maintain. In an important passage of his little work on Laughter he
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: makes a personal moral appeal.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "What life and society require of each of us is a constantly alert
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: attention, that discerns the outlines of the present situation, together
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: with a certain elasticity of mind and body to enable us to adapt
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ourselves in consequence." [Footnote: Laughter, p. 18 (Fr. p. 18).] The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: lack of tension and elasticity gives rise to mental deficiency and to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: grave inadaptability which produces misery and crime. Society demands
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: not only that we live but that we live well. This means that we must be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: truly alive; for Bergson, the moral ideal is to keep spiritually alert.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We must be our real, living selves, and not hide behind the social self
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of hypocrisy and habit. We must avoid being the victims of mechanism or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: automatism. We must avoid at all costs "getting into a rut" morally or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: spiritually. Change and vision are both necessary to our welfare. Where
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there is no vision, no undying fire of idealism, the people perish.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Resistance to change is the sin against the Holy Spirit. Bergson is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: opposed to the conventional view of morality as equivalent to rigidity,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and grasps the important truth that if morality is to be of worth at all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it must lie not in a fixed set of rules, habits, or conventions, but in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a spirit of living. This is of very great ethical importance indeed,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as it means that we must revise many of our standards of character. For
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: example, how often do we hear of one who, holding an obviously false
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: view long and obstinately, is praised as consistent, whereas a mind
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which moves and develops with the times, attempting always to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: adjust itself to changing conditions in its intellectual or material
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: environment, is contemptuously dubbed as "changeable" by the moralists
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of rigidity. We must, however, learn that consistency of character
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: does not mean lack of change. Stanchness of character is too often
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mere obstinate resistance to change. We must therefore be on our guard
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: against those who would run ethics into rigid moulds, and so raise up
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: static concepts and infallible dogmas for beliefs or action. Change
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: must be accepted as a principle which it is both futile and immoral to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ignore, even in the moral life. This does not mean setting up caprice
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or impulsiveness, for in so far as our change of character expresses
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the development of the single movement of our own inner life it will be
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: quite other than capricious, but it will be change, and a change which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is quite consistent, a creative evolution of our personality.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: No merely materialistic ethic can breathe in the atmosphere of Bergson's
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thought, which sets human consciousness in a high place and insists upon
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the fact of Freedom. He maintains a point of view far removed from the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: old naturalistic ethic; he does take some account of "values," freedom,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: creativeness, and joy (as distinct from pleasure). He points out that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Matter, although to a degree the tool of Spirit, is nevertheless the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: enemy who threatens us with a lapse into mere automatism which is only
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the parody of true life. The eternal conflict of Matter and Spirit
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in Evolution demands that we place ourselves on the side of spiritual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rather than merely material values. We must not be like "the man with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the muck rake." Our conceptions of goodness must be not merely static
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: but dynamic, for the moral life is essentially an evolution--"a growth
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in grace." It means a constant "putting on of the new man," never
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "counting oneself to have attained," for spirituality is a progress to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ever new creations, the spiritual life is an unending adventure, and is,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: moreover, one which is hampered and crushed by all refusals to recognize
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that Change is the fundamental feature of the universe. Nothing can
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be more mischievous, more detrimental to moral progress--which is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: ultimately the only progress of value and significance to humanity--than
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the deification of the status quo either in the individual or in society
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as a whole.

text: CHAPTER XI
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: RELATION TO RELIGION AND THEOLOGY
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Avoidance of theological terms--Intuition and faith--God and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Change--Deity not omnipotent but creative and immanent--God as "Creator
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of creators"--Problem of teleology--Stimulus to theology--The need for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: restatements of the nature of God--Men as products and instruments of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: divine activity--Immortality.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: We have seen that Bergson holds no special brief for science, for,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as has been shown, he opposes many of the hypotheses to which science
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: clings. Consequently, some persons possessing only a superficial
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: acquaintance with Bergson, and having minds which still think in the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: exclusive and opposing terms of the conflict of science and religion of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: a generation past, have enthusiastically hailed him as an ally of their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: religion. We must examine carefully how far this is justifiable. It is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: perfectly natural and just that many people, unable to devote time or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: energy to the study of his works, want to know, in regard to Bergson, as
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: about every other great thinker, what is the bearing of his thought on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: their practical theory of life, upon their ideals of existence, upon
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the courage, faith, and hope which enable them to work and live, feeling
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: that life is worth while. We must, however, guard against misuse of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson, particularly such misuse of him as that made in another sphere,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: by the Syndicalists. We find that in France he has been welcomed by the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Modernists of the Roman Catholic Church as an ally, and by not a few
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: liberal and progressive Christian theologians in this country.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: At the outset, we must note that Bergson avoids theological forms
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of expression, because he is well aware that these--especially in a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophical treatise--may give rise to misconceptions. He does not,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: like Kant, attack any specific or traditional argument for Theism; he
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: does not enter into theological controversy. He has not formulated, with
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: any strictness, his conception of God; for he has recognized that an
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: examination of Theism would be of little or no value, which was not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: prefaced by a refutation of mechanism and materialism, and by the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: assertion of some spiritual value in the universe. It is to such a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: labour that Bergson has applied himself; it is only incidentally that
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we find him making remarks on religious or theological conceptions.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: His whole philosophy, however, involves some very important religious
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conceptions and theological standpoints. In France, Bergson has had a

text: Bergson has been cited as a "Mystic" because he preaches a doctrine

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: mystical--but so is all philosophy. We must beware of any attempts to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In concluding this study of Bergson's philosophy, it remains to sum up
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and to review its general merits and deficiencies. We must remember, in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: fairness to Bergson, that he does not profess to offer us A SYSTEM of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophy. In fact, if he were to do so, he would involve himself in a
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: grave inconsistency, for his thought is not of the systematic type. He
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: is opposed to the work of those individual thinkers who have offered
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "systems" to the world, rounded and professedly complete constructions,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: labelled, one might almost say, "the last word in Philosophy." Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: does not claim that his thought is final. His ideal, of which he speaks
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in his lectures on La Perception du Changement--that excellent summary
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of his thought--is a progressive philosophy to which each thinker shall
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: contribute. If we feel disappointed that Bergson has not gone further or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: done more by attempting a solution of some of the fundamental problems
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of our human experience, upon which he has not touched, then we must
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: recollect his own view of the philosophy he is seeking to expound. All
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thinking minds must contribute their quota. A philosophy such as he
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: wishes to promote by establishing a method by his own works will not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be made in a day. "Unlike the philosophical systems properly so called,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: each of which was the individual work of a man of genius, and sprang
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: up as a whole to be taken or left, it will only be built up by the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: collective and progressive effort of many thinkers, of many observers
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: also, completing, correcting, and improving one another." [Footnote:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Introduction to Creative Evolution, p. xiv. (Fr. p. vii).] Both science
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and the older kind of metaphysics have kept aloof from the vital
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: problems of our lives. In one of his curious but brilliant metaphors
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson likens Life to a river over which the scientists have
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: constructed an elaborate bridge, while the laborious metaphysicians
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have toiled to build a tunnel underneath. Neither group of workers has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: attempted to plunge into the flowing tide itself. In the most brilliant
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of his short papers: L'Intuition philosophique, he makes an energetic
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: appeal that philosophy should approach more closely to practical life.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: His thought aims at setting forth, not any system of knowledge, but
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: rather a method of philosophizing; in a phrase, this method amounts to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the assertion that Life is more than Logic, or, as Byron put it, "The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: tree of Knowledge is not the tree of Life."
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: It is because Bergson has much to say that is novel and opposed to older
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: conceptions that a certain lack of proportion occasionally mars his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: thought; for he--naturally enough--frequently lays little emphasis on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: important points which he considers are sufficiently familiar, in order
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to give prominent place and emphasis to some more novel point. Herein
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: lies, it would now appear, the explanation of the seeming disharmony
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: between Intuition and Intellect which was gravely distressing to many in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: his earlier writing on the subject. Later works, however, make a point
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of restoring this harmony, but, as William James has remarked: "We
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: are so subject to the philosophical tradition which treats logos, or
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: discursive thought generally, as the sole avenue to truth, that to fall
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: back on raw, unverbalized life, as more of a revealer, and to think of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: concepts as the merely practical things which Bergson calls them, comes
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: very hard. It is putting off our proud maturity of mind and becoming
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: again as foolish little children in the eyes of reason. But, difficult
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: as such a revolution is, there is no other way, I believe, to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the possession of reality." [Footnote: Lecture on Bergson and his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: anti-intellectualism, in A Pluralistic Universe. It may be remarked
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: here that, although James hailed Bergson as an ally, Bergson cannot
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson's style of writing merits high praise. He is no "dry"
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosopher; he is highly imaginative and picturesque; many of his
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: passages might be styled, like those of Macaulay, "purple," for at times
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: he rises to a high pitch of feeling and oratory. Yet this has been urged
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: against him by some critics. The ironic remark has been repeated, in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: regard to Bergson, which was originally made of William James, by Dr.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Schiller, that his work was "so lacking in the familiar philosophic
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: catch-words, that it may be doubted whether any professor has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: his popularity. The criticism directed against his poetic style, accuses
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: which it is customary to tolerate on the stage of metaphysics, and has
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: preface to Elliot's volume, Modern Science and the Illusions of Bergson,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: p. xvii.] Another critic remarks that "as far as Creative Evolution is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: McCabe: Principles of Evolution, p. 254.] Certainly his language
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: to allege that he substitutes metaphor for proof, for we find, on
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: examination of his numerous and striking metaphors, that they are
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: does not submit analogies as proof, but in illustration of his points.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: As a thinker, Bergson is very difficult to classify. "All classification

text: "idea of the line," the trespassing of space, causes; but he comes very
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: near to denying, in his statements regarding duree pure, any knowledge
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: of the past as past; he overlooks the decisive difference between the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: "no more" and the "not yet" feeling of the child's consciousness, which

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: To take another of his "pure" distinctions, we cannot see any necessity

text: quite unknown and unknowable and unnecessary as an hypothesis. As to his

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: and seems to be the statement of a very profound truth which sheds light
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: on many difficult problems attaching to personality and consciousness,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: for it is the conservation of memories which is the central point in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: individuality. His distinction between the habit of repeating and the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: "pure" memory is a very good and very necessary one. In his study of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: the relation of Soul and Body, we find some of his most meritorious
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: work--his insistence on the uniqueness of Mind and the futility of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: attempts to reduce it to material terms. His treatment of this question

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: or "transmissive" function of the brain. Bergson's criticisms of

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: Determinism. Men were growing impatient of a science claiming so
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: much and yet admittedly unable to explain the really vital factors of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: existence, of which the free action of men is one of the most important.

text: to mould the future, links Bergson again with James, and it is this

author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: both thinkers. This has been pointed out in the consideration of

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: indeed ignores, the influence of transcendent ideas or ideals on the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: and beautiful, and the order of human life becomes more and more guided

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: of moral ideas and ideals with their crude and animal origins and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: environment, to which they are so opposed and to which they are actually

title: Bergson and His Philosophy

text: Ethics.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: There are four problems which confront every evolutionary theory. These
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: concern the origin of: Matter, Life, Consciousness, and Conscience.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson finds it very difficult to account for the origin of Matter, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: it is not clear from what he says why the original consciousness should
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: have made Matter and then be obliged to fight against it in order to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: be free. Then, in speaking of the law of Thermodynamics, he says: "Any
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: material system which should store energy by arresting its degradation
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to some lower level, and produce effects by its sudden liberation, would
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: exhibit something in the nature of Life." This, however, is not
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: very precise, for this would hold true of thunder-clouds and of many
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: machines. In regard to Instinct, it has been pointed out by several
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: experts that Instinct is not so infallible as Bergson makes out. Of the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: mistakes of Instinct he says little. Dr. McDougall in his great work
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: any intelligible account of individuality is its greatest defect.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: I venture to think," he continues, "that the most urgent problem
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the continuity of all life, with the theory of progressive evolution,

text: and with the facts of heredity and biparental reproduction." [Footnote:
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: In the light of such criticism it is important to note that Bergson is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: now giving attention to the problem of personality which he made the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: subject of his Gifford Lectures. It is a highly important problem for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: humanity, and concentration on it seems the demand of the times upon
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: those who feel the urgent need of reflection and who have the ability
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: to philosophize. Can philosophy offer any adequate explanation of human
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: personality, its place and purpose in the cosmos? Why should individual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: systems of energy, little worlds within the world, appear inside the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: unity of the whole, depending on their environment, physical and mental,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for much, but yet capable of freedom and unforeseen actions, and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of creative and progressive development? Further, why should ideals
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: concentrate themselves as it were round such unique centres of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: indeterminateness as these are? On these problems of our origin and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: destiny, in short, on an investigation of human personality, thinkers
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: must concentrate. Humanity will not be satisfied with systems which
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: leave no room for the human soul. Human personality and its experience
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: must have ample place and recognition in any philosophy put forward in
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: these days.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson's work is a magnificent attempt to show us how, in the words
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of George Meredith: "Men have come out of brutishness." His theory
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of evolution is separated from Naturalism by his insistence on human
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: freedom and on the supra-consciousness which is the origin of things;
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: on the other hand, he is separated from the Idealists by his insistence
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: upon the reality of la duree. He contrasts profoundly with Absolute
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Idealism. While in Hegel, Mind is the only truth of Nature, in Bergson,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Life is the only truth of Matter, or we may express it--whereas for
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Hegel the truth of Reality is its ideality, for Bergson the truth of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Reality is its vitality.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: The need for philosophical thought, as Bergson himself points out,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: [Footnote: See the closing remarks in his little work on French
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: philosophy, La Philosophie.] is world-wide. Philosophy aims at bringing
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: all discussion, even that of business affairs, on to the plane of ideas
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and principles. By looking at things from a truly "general" standpoint
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: we are frequently helped to approach them in a really "generous" frame
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of mind, for there is an intimate connexion between the large mind and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the large heart.
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: Bergson has rendered valuable service in calling attention to the need
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: for man to examine carefully his own inner nature, and the deepest worth
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: and significance of his own experiences. For the practical purposes of
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: life, man is obliged to deal with objects in space, and to learn their
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: relations to one another. But this does not exhaust the possibilities
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of his nature. He has himself the reality of his own self-consciousness,
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: his own spiritual existence to consider. Consequently, he can never rest
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: satisfied with any purely naturalistic interpretation of himself. The
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: step of realizing the importance of mental constructions to interpret
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the impressions of the external world, and the applying them to
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: practical needs, was a great advance. Much greater progress, however, is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: there in man's realization of qualities within himself which transcend
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the ordinary dead level of experience, the recognition of the spiritual
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: value of his own nature, of himself as a personality, capable even amid
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the fluctuations of the world about him, and the illusions of sense
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: impressions, of obtaining a foretaste of eternity by a life that has the
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: infinite and the eternal as its inheritance; "He hath set eternity
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: in the heart of man." Man craves other values in life than the purely
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: scientific. "There are more things in heaven and earth than are dreamt
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of" in the philosophies of the materialist or the naturalist. Bergson
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: assures us that the future belongs to a philosophy which will take into
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: account THE WHOLE of what is given. Transcending Body and Intellect is
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: the life of the Spirit, with needs beyond either bodily satisfaction
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: or intellectual needs craving its development, satisfaction and fuller
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: realization. The man who seeks merely bodily satisfaction lives the life

author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: of the animal; even the man who poses as an intellectual finds himself
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: entangled ultimately in relativity, missing the uniqueness of all
title: Bergson and His Philosophy
author: Gunn, John Alexander

text: things--his own life included. An intuitive philosophy introduces us

text: to the spiritual life and makes us conscious, individually and
title: Bergson and His Philosophy

title: Bergson and His Philosophy
